139.01 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY.
   The Director of Public Safety shall be appointed by the Mayor and the
Director may be the same person who holds the office of Mayor. The Director of
Public Safety shall be the executive head of the Police and Fire Departments
and shall have all powers and duties connected with and incident to the
appointment, regulation and government of such Departments. The Director of
Public Safety shall receive such compensation as Council may from time to time
provide by ordinance of the City.
(Ord. 1983-66. Passed 7-19-83.)
139.02 AUTHORITY TO ISSUE PRIVATE POLICE COMMISSIONS.
   The Director of Public Safety, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.05 is authorized to
commission private police officers not in classified services of the City under
such rules and regulations as Council shall grant.
(Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.03 UNIFORM RULES AND REGULATIONS; BOND; FEE.
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to prescribe rules and
regulations and the uniform which shall be worn by such private police officers
wherever and whenever their services are conducted. Such private police
officers shall each give bond, by a bonding company authorized by law in the
State, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000) to the satisfaction of the
Director of Public Safety. There shall be a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per
year or any portion thereof. All renewal fees shall be due and payable on
January 1.
(Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.04 UNIFORMS NOT TO BE COPIES.
   No person, not a member of the Police or Fire Department, shall wear a
uniform, cap, badge or buttons similar to or in imitation of the official
uniform, cap, badge or buttons in use at the time by the members of the Police
and Fire Departments of the City.
(Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.05 PRIVATE POLICE COMMISSION.
   (a)    No person shall receive a private police commission unless such
person is licensed to do so in conformity and as provided in Ohio R.C. Chapter
4749, and as provided in this chapter. The issuance of a private police
commission shall not of itself constitute authority to carry concealed
firearms.
   (b)    No person shall perform the business of private investigation as
defined under Ohio R.C. 4749.01(B) within the boundaries of the City unless
such person is the holder of a valid private police commission issued by this
City.
(Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
   (c)    No person shall be a watchman, guard, private patrolman, private
investigator or other person whose primary duty is to protect persons or
property, unless such person is the holder of a valid private police commission
issued by this City, save and except those persons, corporations or entities as
specifically excluded under Ohio R.C. 4749.01(C)(1) through (6). (Ord.1982-2.
Passed 1-5-82.)
139.06 APPLICATION FOR PRIVATE POLICE COMMISSION.
   All applicants in addition to complying with Ohio R.C. Chapter 4749 and any
such administrative rules promulgated by the State Department of Commerce,
Division of Licensing shall:
   (a)    Fill out, upon a form to be provided by the Director of Public
Safety, a statement giving the applicant's full name, residence, places of
residence for five years previous to the present address, age, height, weight,
color of hair and eyes, place of birth, length of residence in Cuyahoga County,
whether a citizen of the United States, place of employment, marital status,
whether ever arrested or convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor, whether ever
summoned to court, whether driving license has ever been revoked, and if so,
for what cause, which statement shall be signed and filed with the Director of
Public Safety as a permanent record.
   (b)    Failure to list arrests or any other information desired by the
Director of Public Safety shall be considered falsifying the application and
the application shall be subject to rejection. All applicants for special
police work as such private police officers must be fingerprinted, and the
Director of Public Safety through the Police Department shall cause a complete
record check to be made of the applicant's character, and may obtain any other
information he may desire. (Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.07 PRIVATE POLICE IDENTIFICATION.
   (a)    A commission card, with photograph attached as issued by the City
shall be carried by such private police officer in order to identify such
officer to the Police Department, showing that such private police officer has
been qualified to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)    Each commissioned private police officer shall, upon demand of an
inspector of licenses or a police officer of the Police Department, exhibit
such commission card and photograph for inspection.
(Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.08 ANIMAL WARDEN.
   (a)    There is hereby established for the City the position of Animal
Warden.
   (b)    Appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor. Such
appointment shall be for such period of time and under such conditions as may
be determined at the time of the appointment and shall be subject to
termination by the Mayor at any time.
   (c)    An Animal Warden appointed under the provisions of this section shall
have the power to enforce all provisions of Chapter
505 of the Codified Ordinances in the same manner and to the same extent as
though he or she were a member of the Police Department. The powers of an
Animal Warden shall specifically include the power to issue citations, cause
arrests for the violation of any provision of such chapter and seize and
impound animals pursuant to said chapter.
   (d)    An Animal Warden appointed under the provisions of this section shall
perform such duties as the Director of Public Safety shall assign and prescribe
for the office.
(Ord. 2024-007. Passed 1-16-24.)
139.99 PENALTY
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. (Ord. 1979-137. Passed 11-20-79.)
                                                                                                   
CHAPTER 141
Police Department
   EDITOR’S NOTE: House Bill 642, enacted by the 1965 session of the 106th Ohio
General Assembly, established Ohio Revised Code Chapter 742 which creates a
Statewide disability and pension fund for policemen and firemen and abolishes
all municipal police and fire relief and pension funds as of January 1, 1967.

141.01 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   There is hereby created the position of Chief of Police.
(Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.02 POLICE OFFICERS.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of police officer for the
Municipality, in such numbers as the Director of Public Safety may appoint with
the consent and confirmation of Council.
   (b)   Such police officers when appointed shall perform:
      (1)   The duties enjoined on them by the laws of Ohio and the ordinances
of the Municipality;
      (2)   The duties usually performed by police officers; and
      (3)   Such duties as are designated and directed by the Director of
Public Safety. (Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.03 REGULATIONS GOVERNING APPOINTMENTS.
   Appointments hereafter made to the Police Department shall be made in
accordance with the following conditions and regulations in addition to the
rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission:
   (a)   Application shall be made in writing to be presented by the Civil
Service Commission and shall set forth such information as required by the
Commission.
   (b)   Each applicant shall file a complete set of fingerprints.
   (c)   Each applicant shall satisfactorily pass a physical examination and
submit satisfactory proof thereof.
   (d)   No person shall be appointed to the Department unless such person:
      (1)   Has reached the age of twenty-one and has not reached the age of
thirty-five on the date of his appointment to the Police Department.
      (2)   Is of good moral character as evidenced by the statements of three
persons, other than relatives of the applicant.
      (3)   Is not a habitual drunkard or drug addict and has never been
convicted of a felony.
      (4)   Has satisfactorily passed a competitive examination in such form as
may be prescribed by the Municipality, and is in the top five of qualified and
available applicants on the certified list.
      (5)   Is a citizen of the United States.
      (6)   Effective June 1, 2015, agrees to live within the county of
Cuyahoga or a county immediately adjacent to Cuyahoga County within one year of
appointment and maintain the same throughout the applicant's employment with
the City. (Ord. 2015-057. Passed 5-19-15.)
141.04 APPOINTMENT OF SERGEANTS AND LIEUTENANTS.
   (a)   Not more than five of the City’s deputy police officers may be
designated to hold the rank of Lieutenant. Such designation, when the same is
deemed advisable and necessary, shall be made by the Director of Public Safety
subject to the rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission. No member
of the Police Department shall be designated to such rank unless he or she has
served a minimum of one year of continuous service as Sergeant in the
Department.
   (b)   Not more than nine of the City’s police officers may be designated to
hold the rank of Sergeant. Such designation, when the same is deemed advisable
and necessary, shall be made by the Director of Public Safety subject to the
rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission. No member of the
Department shall be designated to such rank unless he or she has served a
minimum of four years of continuous service as a deputy police officer in the
Department.
   (c)   Whenever two or more deputy police officers within the Department are
eligible for promotion to a higher rank, the Director of Public Safety may
order a competitive examination to be conducted in accordance with the rules
and regulations provided by the Civil Service Commission. (Ord. 2021-050.
Passed 5-4-21.)
141.05 UNIFORMS.
   All regular members of the Police Department, while on active duty as
members of the Department, are hereby required to wear police uniforms
prescribed by the Director of Public Safety, such uniforms to be purchased
through a uniform allowance. Such uniforms shall be and remain the property of
the member of the Department.
(Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   There are hereby established general rules for the duties and conduct of the
members of the Police Department. Such rules may be promulgated, amended and/or
repealed as provided in Section
139.01 of the Codified Ordinances. All members of the Department shall abide by
and conform to such rules.
   Each member of the Department shall be furnished with a copy of the rules
and regulations which he shall, at all times, keep in his possession. Each
member shall make himself thoroughly familiar with its contents.
(Ord. 1977-149. Passed 11-15-77.)
141.07 PROBATIONARY NATURE OF APPOINTMENT.
   In the event an officer is appointed under this chapter as a police officer,
except such as are now holding office as permanent police officers, such
appointment shall be deemed to be for a probationary period of one year of
continuous service, and no such appointment shall be deemed final until such
appointee has satisfactorily served his probationary period and the appointment
has been made final by the action of the Director of Public Safety, Chief of
Police and as prescribed by the rules and regulations of the Civil Service
Commission. Any police officer hereafter appointed to permanent status after
having served such probationary period shall be appointed as a police officer.
(Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.08 RESERVE POLICE UNIT; ADMINISTRATION.
   There is hereby established a Reserve Police Unit within the Police
Department of the City. The Director of Public Safety shall be the executive
head of the Reserve Police Unit. He shall make all appointments and removals of
reserve police officers, subject to any general regulations prescribed by
Council by ordinance. Further, he shall prescribe rules and regulations for the
organization, training, administration, control and conduct of the Reserve
Police Unit. Members of the Reserve Police Unit are not eligible for membership
in the Police and Firemen's Pension and Disability Fund. Members of the Reserve
Police Unit shall not be in the classified service of the City.
(Ord. 1981-20. Passed 3-17-81.)
141.09 DUTIES OF RESERVE POLICE.
   Reserve policemen shall be on active duty at and for such times as they
shall be assigned to active duty by either the Chief of Police or the Director
of Public Safety and while so on active duty, pursuant to such assignments,
shall perform:
   (a)    All duties enjoined on them by the laws of the State and ordinances
of the City;
   (b)    All duties usually performed by patrolmen or reserve policemen; and
   (c)    Such duties as are designated and directed by the Chief of Police and
the Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 1981-20. Passed 3-17-81.)
141.10 PROBATIONARY NATURE OF RESERVE POLICE APPOINTMENTS.
   In the event of the appointment of any person as a reserve policeman,
pursuant to provisions of this chapter, such appointment shall be deemed to be
for a probationary period of one year and no such appointment shall be deemed
final until such appointee has satisfactorily served his probationary period
and the appointment has been made final by the action of the Director of Public
Safety, subject to general regulations prescribed by Council by ordinance. Such
appointee may at any time within such one year probationary period be removed
from office by action of the Director of Public Safety, subject to general
regulations prescribed by Council by ordinance.
(Ord. 1981-20. Passed 3-17-81.)
141.11 SCHOOL GUARDS.
   The Director of Public Safety is hereby authorized to appoint such number of
school guards as he deems necessary in order to assure the proper protection of
the children of the Municipality attending schools within the Municipality.
(Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.12 POLICE DISPATCHERS.
   (a)    The position of Dispatcher Clerk for the City is hereby created.
   (b)    The positions of full-time and part-time Dispatcher and Dispatcher
Trainee for the City are hereby created.
   (c)    Appointment to the positions of Dispatcher Clerk, full-time and part-
time Dispatcher and Dispatcher Trainee shall be made by the Director of Public
Safety.
   (d)    The Dispatcher Clerk shall perform such duties as the Director of
Public Safety or the Chief of Police assign and prescribe for the office.
   (e)    A full-time Dispatcher shal1 perform such duties as the Director of
Public Safety or the Chief of Police assign and prescribe for the office.
   (f)   A part-time Dispatcher shall perform such duties as the Director of
Public Safety or the Chief of Police assign and prescribe for the office.
   (g)    The time of employment and hours to be worked are to be determined by
the Mayor or the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 1970-35. Passed 3-17-70.)
141.13 DETECTIVE BUREAU.
   (a)    There is hereby established a Detective Bureau within the Police
Department.
   (b)    The Chief of Police is authorized to assign such number of regular
members of the Department to serve in the Detective Bureau as he deems
necessary, one of whom shall be designated as Officer in Charge. Members of the
Bureau shall perform such duties as assigned by the Police Chief.
(Ord. 1977-3. Passed 1-4-77.)
141.14 JUVENILE BUREAU.
   (a)    There is hereby established a Juvenile Bureau within the Police
Department.
   (b)    The Director of Public Safety may assign two regular members of the
Police Department to serve in the Juvenile Bureau, one of whom may be
designated as Juvenile Sergeant and be in charge of the Bureau, and one of whom
may be designated as Juvenile Patrolman. Members of the Bureau shall perform
such duties as are assigned by the Chief of Police. (Ord. 1970-132. Passed 8-4-
70.)
141.15 POLICE INVESTIGATION FUND.
   (a)    The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him in writing shall
have sole custody of and jurisdiction over the Police Investigation Fund. The
Fund shall be used by the Police Department for confidential investigations to
determine whether the criminal laws of the City, State or Federal government
have been violated. However, no part of the Fund shall be paid directly or
indirectly to any person employed by the City.
   (b)    The Chief of Police shall account for expenditures from the Fund by
delivering to the Director of Finance appropriate vouchers and receipts
evidencing each and every expenditure from the Fund and he shall, annually, at
the close of the fiscal year, provide a written report to the Director of
Public Safety and the Director of Finance showing a complete and adequate
reporting of the receipts and expenditures of the Fund, together with a
description of the purpose of the expenditure.
   (c)    When the Fund has been reduced to less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) the Chief of Police shall apply to Council for additional moneys.
(Ord. 1972-24. Passed 3-7-72.)
141.16 EXECUTIVE SAFETY ADVISOR.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Executive Safety Advisor to
the Police Department.
   (b)    The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor subject
to the approval of Council. The Advisor shall hold office at the pleasure of
the Mayor.
   (c)    The Executive Safety Advisor of the Police Department shall perform
such duties as the Mayor and Chief of Police assign and prescribe for the
office.
(Ord. 1976-13. Passed 1-20-76.)
141.17 EXECUTIVE OFFICER.
   (a)    The position of Executive Officer of the Police Department for the
City is hereby created.
   (b)    The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor, and the
Executive Officer shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (c)    The Executive Officer shall perform such duties as the Mayor and
Police Chief assign and prescribe for the office and shall assume the duties of
the Police Chief in the absence of the Police Chief.
   (d)    The Executive Officer shall be appointed from the Police Department
and must be of a rank no less than lieutenant.
   (e)    The position of Executive Officer is deemed to be in the unclassified
service. In the event of resignation or removal, he shall be entitled, unless
his removal has been for reasons which would have constituted grounds therefor
under the provisions of the law relating to Civil Service, to be restored to
the highest position in the Police Department held by him prior to his
appointment as Executive Officer.
(Ord. 1977-150. Passed 11-15-77.)
141.18 JAIL FEES.
   (a)    There is hereby established a rate of eighty-five dollars ($85.00)
per day for the use of the Warrensville Heights Jail facility for the housing
of prisoners by other governmental entities.
   
   (b)    The Chief of Police or any personnel of the Police Department
designated by him shall keep an accurate record of the use made of the City
Jail facilities by any other governmental entity and shall promptly invoice the
governmental entity using such facilities and send a carbon copy thereof to the
Director of Finance of the City.
(Ord. 1989-11. Passed 2-7-89.)
141.19 PART-TIME PATROL OFFICERS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Part-Time Patrol Officer
which shall not be subject to civil service and which position shall be filled
by the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)   Such Part-Time Patrol Officers when appointed shall perform:
      (1)   The duties enjoined on them by the laws of the State of Ohio and
the ordinances of the Municipality;
      (2)   The duties usually and customarily performed by police officers;
      (3)   Such duties as are designated and directed by the Director of
Public Safety and/or Chief of Police.
   (c)   Part-Time Patrol Officers are hereby authorized to preserve and
enforce the laws of the State of Ohio and the City of Warrensville Heights.
This authority contemplates that such officers shall have the right to bear
arms and have authority to make arrests. Part-Time Patrol Officers shall be
employed on a part-time basis and are not eligible for participation in the
Police and Firemen’s Pension and Disability Fund and shall be in the
unclassified service of the City. Part-Time Patrol Officers are not eligible to
accumulate sick and vacation time or other benefits which may be provided to
full-time Patrol Officers unless specifically provided for by ordinance.
   (d)   Part-Time Patrol Officers shall be subject to the rules and
regulations of the Police Department and shall comply with any and all
additional rules and regulations in regard to training, administration, control
and duties as may be from time to time promulgated by the Chief of Police,
subject to the approval of the Safety Director.
   (e)   Part-Time Patrol Officers shall be paid within the pay ranges
established from time to time by Council.
   (f)   Part-Time Patrol Officers shall receive an annual uniform allowance in
an amount established from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 1996-10. Passed 4-16-96.)
141.20 MUNICIPAL TOWING CONTRACTS AND RATES.
   (a)   The Mayor, subject to approval by formal resolution of Council, is
authorized to enter into agreement with at least two and not more than three
operators of towing service who shall be responsible for providing towing
service within the City.
   (b)   Standard towing rates from any point within the City shall not
exceeding the following:
Service                                  Fee
Automobile tow                           $175.00 plus any applicable tax
Motorcycle tow                           $210.00plus any applicable tax
Flat bed/dolly tow                       $210.00plus any applicable tax
Winch out                                $50.00 minimum
Automobile/motorcycle storage            $25.00/day
Semi-truck tow*                          $300.00/unit
*anything over 26,000 GVW (gross vehicle
weight)
Semi-truck storage                       $30.00/day/unit
City-owned vehicles                      No cost
 
   *It shall be at the discretion of the Chief of Police, Prosecutor or the
Prosecutor’s designee to release all towed vehicles at no cost.
   (c)   Each operator shall maintain in force during the period of the
agreement, Commercial General Liability Insurance in limits of not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000) for bodily injury and property damage. The
City shall be named as additional insured by endorsement to the policy for
activities directly connected with or arising out of the authority created by
this chapter. The operators of the towing service shall pay the cost of
insurance and provide a Certificate of Insurance evidencing the insurance
limits thereof to the Finance Director.
   (d)   The City shall not in any event, be responsible for unpaid towing
charges.
   (e)   The operators of the towing service shall save harmless the City from
any and all loss, actions or causes of actions which directly or indirectly
arise out of or are the result of such towing activity, and shall further
provide notice of such indemnification to its insurer.
(Ord. 2022-092. Passed 7-19-22.)

143.01 FIRE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS; UNIFORMS.
   (a)   There is hereby created a Fire Department for the Municipality. The
members of the Fire Department shall consist of a Chief, and such officers and
such firemen on active full-time duty as the Director of Public Safety may
appoint and such part-time firemen appointed by the Director. All such officers
shall continue in office until removed for the causes and in the manner
prescribed by law or regulation, or until resignation.
   (b)   All full-time members of the Department while on active duty as a
member of the Department are hereby required to wear Department uniforms
prescribed by the Director of Public Safety. Such uniforms shall be purchased
through a uniform allowance provided for and shall be and remain the property
of the member of the Department.
(Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.02 JURISDICTION AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Fire Department shall have jurisdiction over all matters
pertaining to fire prevention, equipment, quarters, fire fighting, the
installation, supervision and maintenance of a fire alarm signal and
communication system, and the enforcement of fire laws and ordinances.
   (b)   Every full-time salaried officer and member of the Department shall
devote his entire time to its service.
(Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.03 CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Fire Chief shall devote his full time to the duties of such office. He
shall be on active duty in performance of the duties of his office not less
than eight hours per day for not less than five days in each and every calendar
week, and shall remain on call for the performance of the duties of his office
on a twenty-four hour per day basis.
   During any period of absence or inability of the Chief while on vacation or
for any other reason, the highest ranking officer of the Department below the
office of Chief shall exercise the authority of the Chief as Acting Fire Chief.
   The Chief shall have such authority as is necessary for the efficient
discharge of the duties of the Department. The Chief’s authority shall include,
but not be limited to, the following:
   (a)   Such authority as is granted by law.
   (b)   The duty and authority to promulgate such regulations for the conduct
of the Department and the promotion of firemen as he deems necessary.
   (c)   The duty to enforce adherence to the regulations of the Department and
such discipline as is necessary and proper for the proper and efficient conduct
of the Department.
   (d)   The authority to direct the response of the Department to fire calls
in such other subdivisions as have agreements with this Municipality for such
service; provided that such response can be made without unnecessarily
jeopardizing the welfare of this Municipality.
   (e)   Such police power as is necessary to the proper execution of the
duties of the Department.
   (f)   The authority to call for aid from other subdivisions when the welfare
of the Municipality requires such action.
   (g)   Authority, in cases of emergency, to deputize as firemen such persons
as are necessary to protect the lives and property of the inhabitants of this
Municipality. Such persons so designated shall be firemen for the duration of
such emergency.
   (h)   Extinguishing all fires with the least possible damage to life and
property and prevention of unnecessary damage by water.
   (i)   He shall make official report of his action and the action of the
officers and members under his command as may be provided by law or the rules
of the Department.
   (j)    He shall have power, and it shall be his duty, to demolish buildings
and parts of buildings which, in his judgment, may cause further damage to life
or property or which, in his judgment, it may be necessary to demolish to
prevent the spread of fire.
   (k)    He shall, in writing, submit the resignation of any member of the
Department, or notice thereof, and transmit all reports and communications of
the Department, with his endorsement, to the Mayor as the nature of same may be
required by law or the rules of the Department.
   (l)    He may suspend from duty any person of the Department for any of the
following causes:
       (1)    For intoxication while on duty or while in uniform.
       (2)    For the use of intoxicating liquor to excess.
       (3)    For being engaged directly or indirectly as a vendor of
intoxicating liquor.
       (4)    For willful disobedience of any order lawfully issued to him by a
superior officer in the Department.
      (5)    For incompetency to perform the duties of his office.
      (6)    For conviction of any felony or misdemeanor against the laws of
the United States or the laws of the State of Ohio, or for conviction of
violating any lawful ordinance of the Municipality.
      (7)    For willfully or continually violating any of the rules or
regulations of the Department.
      (8)    For habitually contracting debts which he is unable or unwilling
to pay, or for refusing to discharge his lawful obligations.
Every suspension shall be immediately reported to the Director of Public Safety
and the Chief shall appear before such officials whenever requested for the
purpose of prosecuting or assisting in the prosecution of any person suspended
by him.
   (m)    The Chief may reprimand or deprive of vacation days or days off any
member of the classified division for the following causes:
      (1)    For intoxication while not on duty.
      (2)    For indecent or profane language while on duty or in uniform.
       (3)    For disrespect to a superior officer in the Department.
      (4)    For any neglect of duty.
      (5)    For absence without leave.
      (6)    For conduct unbecoming a fireman, officer or gentleman.
      (7)    For neglecting to report his change of residence to the officer in
charge of his company.
      (8)    For any violation of any rule or regulation of the Department.
   (n)    He shall upon all occasions see that the laws of the State and
ordinances of the Municipality applicable to the Fire Department are faithfully
observed. He shall promulgate and enforce all orders of the Director of Public
Safety and the Chairman of the Safety Committee of Council. He shall have the
right to issue general, special or verbal orders wherever he may deem it
necessary.
      (Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.04 QUALIFICATIONS FOR MEMBERS.
   Members appointed to the Department shall meet all the requirements of State
law, the rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission and the
following qualifications:
   (a)   Shall be between the ages of twenty-one to thirty-four, inclusive;
   (b)   Shall be of good moral character and not convicted of any felony;
   (c)   Shall be of good moral character, to be evidenced by statements of
three persons other than relatives of the applicant;
   (d)   Shall not be a habitual alcoholic or drug addict;
   (e)   Shall satisfactorily pass physical and mental examinations;
   (f)   Shall file complete sets of fingerprints;
   (g)   Shall apply in writing setting forth such information as is
established or required by the rules and regulations of the Civil Service
Commission and the regulations of the Fire Department.
      (Ord. 2019-097. Passed 7-16-19.)
143.05 PART-TIME FIREMEN.
   Any person hereafter appointed to the Department as a part-time fireman
shall be first appointed to a three-month probationary period.
   After satisfactorily serving such probationary period and passing an
examination on fire duties and conduct, such person may be appointed for a
period of six months as a temporary member of the Department as a part-time
fireman.
   After satisfactorily serving for such six-month period, such person then may
be appointed as a permanent member of the Department as a part-time fireman.
   All part-time firemen shall be in the unclassified designation of the Civil
Service.
(Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.06 FIRE DEPARTMENT REGULATIONS.
   There are established general rules for the duties and conduct of the
members of the Fire Department. Such rules are made a part hereof as though
attached hereto and as though fully rewritten herein. All members of the
Department shall abide by and conform to such rules.
   Each member of the Department shall be furnished with a copy of the rules
and regulations which he shall, at all times, keep in his possession. Each
member shall make himself thoroughly familiar with its contents.
(Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.07 RESIGNATIONS; FURLOUGHS.
   Resignation from the Department shall be in the form prescribed by the
regulations and shall be effective upon acceptance by Council.
   Members in good standing entering the armed forces of the United States
shall be deemed furloughed and shall retain seniority and other rights of
service during their absence.
   Furloughs may be granted by the Chief for a period not to exceed six months
with approval of the Safety Director upon written application therefor. Absence
beyond six months without approved extensions shall be grounds for dismissal
except as otherwise provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.08 REIMBURSEMENTS OF CHIEF AND DEPARTMENT MEMBERS.
   Upon the approval of the Safety Director, the Fire Chief or other members of
the Fire Department may be reimbursed for time spent and expenses incurred in
attending schools, outside meetings, instruction classes or demonstrations.
(Ord. 1979-4. Passed 1-2-79.)
143.09 SERVICES IN EXCHANGE FOR INSURANCE COMPANY PROCEEDS.
   The City will provide ambulance emergency squad service in exchange for an
assignment of insurance company proceeds available to the user, whether a
resident or nonresident. Ambulance emergency squad service shall include, but
not be limited to, transporting individuals to a medial facility and arriving
at a location where medical attention is requested, even if the individual
declines to be transported to a medical facility. The City will not charge or
collect from residents any amount of money in excess of the amount of the
insurance company proceeds. Any costs that are not covered by the resident’s
insurance shall be waived. The nonresident user is responsible for any amount
not paid by his or her insurance. This section shall be effective for all
ambulance emergency squad services rendered on or after January 1, 2024.
(Ord. 2023-111. Passed 11-8-23.)
143.10 ELECTRONIC CLAIMS FILING SYSTEM; COLLECTION.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into an agreement with the an
ambulance billing company, which will provide an electronic claims filing
system for the purpose of collecting insurance proceeds available to residents
and nonresidents, and amounts not covered by the insurance companies of
nonresidents as provided in Section
143.09. If the ambulance billing company is not able to collect the uncovered
amounts pursuant to the terms in said agreement, the City may contract with
another entity to collect the uncovered amounts.
(Ord. 2023-111. Passed 11-8-23.)
143.11 INSPECTIONS BY FIRE DEPARTMENT; FEES.
   (a)   A fee schedule for inspections performed by the Fire Department is
established as follows:

143.12 DEPLOYMENT OF EQUIPMENT AND PERSONNEL TO MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENTS; FEE.
   (a)   The City Fire Department shall initiate a new user fee for the
delivery of Fire Department services, personnel, supplies, and equipment to the
scene of motor vehicle accidents. The rate of the user fee shall be that which
is the costs incurred, which includes any services, personnel, supplies and
equipment and may fluctuate based on the needs of the accident.
   (b)   The user fee shall be filed against the motor vehicle insurance
liability coverage, representing an add-on-cost of the claim for damages of the
vehicles, property and/or injuries. The claim costs shall be filed against the
insurance coverage of the cited or responsible insured nonresident party or
parties as determined by the police or other litigating entities. It has been
determined by the National Insurance Institute, that such claims filed by the
Fire Department, will not cause an increase to the premiums of the insured
other than what would have normally occurred with the insured from bad credit,
or high risk driver.
   (c)   Upon authorization of Council, the Mayor and/or Finance Director will
be authorized to contract with an outside agency specializing in the billing of
Fire Department services for motor vehicle accidents, for collection of user
fees as a result of Fire Department services being provided.
   (d)   All amounts collected as a result of this section shall be placed into
a fund as established by the Finance Director to be used exclusively for
personnel, supplies and equipment for the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2023-111. Passed 11-8-23.)
143.13 FIRE SAFETY INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   A fee schedule for inspections at child daycare facilities, foster
homes and other state or county required special annual inspections performed
by the Fire Department is established as follows:

   (b)   The Fire Department is hereby authorized and directed to collect
inspection fees in accordance with the schedule in subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 2004-036. Passed 4-20-04.)
143.14 ARSON INVESTIGATOR; DUTIES.
   (a)   The Arson Investigator’s duties and responsibilities shall be vested
in the position of Fire Chief or his/her designee and shall be a full-time
member of the Fire Department.
   (b)   The Arson Investigator shall perform all of the duties and
requirements as established by the Ohio R.C. 737.27: To be present at all
fires; investigate the cause thereof; examine witnesses; compel the attendance
of witnesses and the production of books and papers; and to perform all other
acts necessary to the discharge of such duties.
   (c)   The Arson Investigator may administer oaths, make arrests and enter,
for the purpose of examination, any building which, in his opinion, is in
danger from fire. The Investigator shall report his proceedings to the Fire
Chief at such times as required.
(Ord. 2004-031. Passed 3-16-04.)
143.15 IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION DETECTION AND MITIGATION PROGRAM.
   EDITOR’S NOTE: The City of Warrensville Heights adopts the Policy/Procedure
for Identity Theft Prevention, Detection and Mitigation Program (“Program”)
attached to Resolution 2009-049, as required by the Rules, which will be
implemented by the Fire Department of the City. The Fire Chief shall be the
official within the administration responsible for oversight, ongoing
development, implementation and administration of the program. (Res. 2009-049.
Passed 9-1-09.)
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 145
Department of Buildings

CROSS REFERENCES
Zoning Code enforcement - see P. & Z. Ch.
1123
Building regulations - see Part Thirteen - Building Code
Housing Code enforcement - see BLDG. Ch.
1380
 
 
 
145.01 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; ADMINISTRATION.
   There is hereby established the Department of Buildings, to be administered
by the Building Commissioner subject to the laws of the State of Ohio and the
ordinances of the Municipality.
(Ord. 1958-2. Passed 1-2-58.)
145.02 DUTIES OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
      The duties of the Building Commissioner, or his designees, shall be as
follows:
      (a)    To administer and enforce all laws of Ohio and ordinances of this
Municipality relating to the construction, alteration, construction, safety,
maintenance, repair, moving or razing of all buildings, structures, elevators,
heating apparatus, gas fittings, house drainage and plumbing utilities, steam
boilers, electrical wiring, prevention of smoke, fire escapes and other fire
protective devices.
     (b)    To act on all applications for permits to erect, construct,
install, enlarge, alter, repair or remove any wall or any building, structure,
heating or ventilating apparatus or any part thereof and to pay the fees
collected by him through such activities into the Municipal Treasury each
month.
      (c)    To examine and inspect all buildings in course of erection,
construction, alteration, safety, repair or removal as often as necessary to
insure efficient supervision and construction in conformity with the plans and
specifications.
      (d)    To keep complete records of all permits issued, fees collected and
inspections made, as well as other official work performed and to submit to
Council and report on such activities once each year.
      (e)    To possess and perform all of the duties of the building official
as set forth in the Council of American Building Officials (CABO) Dwelling Code
and the Ohio Basic Building Code, including the examination of all building
plans before a permit shall be issued. (Ord. 2015-138. Passed 12-1-15.)
145.03 PLUMBING AND HEATING INSPECTION.
   (a)    The positions of Plumbing Inspector and Heating Inspector are hereby
combined so as to create the position of Plumbing and Heating Inspector.
   (b)    The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor subject
to the approval of Council. Such appointment shall be for such period of time
and under such conditions as may be determined at the time of the appointment,
and shall be subject to termination by the Mayor.
   (c)    The duties of the Plumbing and Heating Inspector re heating
installations shall be as follows:
      (1)    Administer and enforce all laws and ordinances relating to the
installation, maintenance, alteration and repair of heating installations;
      (2)    Act on all applications and permits for the installation,
maintenance, alteration and repair of heating equipment, and to pay the fees
collected by him through such permits, or otherwise in the performance of his
duties, into the Municipal Treasury each month;
      (3)    Inspect and test all heating installations and equipment as
required by the laws of Ohio and the ordinances of this Municipality;
      (4)    Keep complete records of all permits issued, fees collected and
inspections made, as well as other official work performed, and to submit to
Council his report on such activities once each year.
   (d)    The duties of the Plumbing and Heating Inspector re plumbing shall be
as follows:
      (1)    Administer and enforce all laws of Ohio and ordinances of the
Municipality relating to the installation, maintenance, alteration and repair
of all piping, traps and fixtures of a building drainage or plumbing system,
and the installation, maintenance, alteration and repair of all piping, meters
and fixtures of a building gas system;
      (2)    Act on all applications for permits for the installation,
maintenance, alteration and repair of all piping, traps and fixtures of
building drainage, plumbing and gas systems, and to pay the fees collected by
him through the activities of his office into the Municipal Treasury each
month;
      (3)    Inspect and test all the piping, traps, meters and fixtures of
plumbing, drainage and gas systems of buildings, as required by the laws of
Ohio and the ordinance of this Municipality;
      (4)    Keep complete records of all permits issued, fees collected and
inspections made, as well as other official work performed, and to submit to
Council a report on such activities once each year.
(Ord. 1958-2. Passed 1-2-58.)
145.04 ELECTRICAL INSPECTION.
   The Electrical Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by Council and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   The duties of the Electrical Inspector shall be as follows:
   (a)    Administer and enforce all laws and ordinances relating to the
installation, maintenance, alteration and repair of electrical wiring and
equipment;
   (b)   Act on all applications and permits for the installation, maintenance,
alteration and repair of electrical wiring and equipment and to pay the fees
collected by him through such permits or otherwise in the performance of his
duties, into the Municipal Treasury each month;
   (c)    Inspect and test all electrical wiring and equipment as required by
the laws of Ohio and the ordinances of this Municipality; and
   (d)    Keep complete records of all permits issued, fees collected and
inspections made, as well as other official work performed and to submit to
Council his report on such activities once each year.
      (Ord. 1958-2. Passed 1-2-58.)
145.05 APPOINTMENT OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   The Building Commissioner shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by Council and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   All fees charged and collected by the Commissioner shall be paid into the
City Treasury on the first day of the following month from whence they have
been received.
(Ord. 1969-202. Passed 12-2-69.)
145.06 ASSISTANT BUILDING COMMISSIONER AND HOUSING INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The position of Assistant Building Commissioner and Housing Inspector
is hereby created.
   (b)    The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor, subject
to the approval of Council. Such appointment shall be for such period of time
and under such conditions as may be determined by the Mayor.
(Ord.1972-30. Passed 3-7-72.)
145.07 BONDS.
   The Building Commissioner shall give bond in the sum of fifteen thousand
dollars ($15,000) for the faithful performance of his duties, the premium for
which shall be paid by the Municipality. Such bond and its sureties shall be
subject to the approval of the Mayor.
145.08 HOUSING INSPECTORS.
   (a)    The positions of Housing Inspectors are hereby created.
   (b)    Appointments to such positions shall be made by the Mayor, subject to
the approval of Council. Such appointments shall be for such period of time and
under such conditions as may be determined by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1973-27. Passed 4-3-73.)
145.09 CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR.
   (a)    The position of Concrete Construction Supervisor is hereby created.
   (b)    Appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor and shall be
subject to termination by the Mayor.
   (c)    The Concrete Construction Supervisor shall perform the duties of
supervising a crew and engaging in concrete construction and repair work done
by the City. In addition, the Supervisor shall perform any other duties
assigned by the Mayor or Director of Public Service. (Ord. 1969-102. Passed 5-
20-69.)
145.10 PLAT CLERK.
   (a)    The position of Plat Clerk is hereby created.
   (b)    Appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor and the Plat
Clerk shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (c)    The Plat Clerk shall have the duties of maintaining and keeping
current the Plat Book of the City and shall do any and all things necessary and
incidental to the maintenance of the Plat Book.
(Ord. 1969-68. Passed 3-18-69. )
145.11 ASSISTANT ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The position of Assistant Electrical Inspector for the City is hereby
created.
   (b)    The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor, subject
to the approval of Council.
   (c)    The salary for such position shall be the sum of one dollar ($1.00)
per year during the training period, and the training period shall be a minimum
of one year. Upon the termination of the training period, the appointment to
such position may be made permanent by the Mayor, subject to the approval of
Council at a salary to be determined at the time of the permanent appointment.
   (d)    The Assistant Electrical Inspector shall be a journeyman electrician
at the start of the training period and must be approved by the State Board of
Examiners.
(Ord. 1972-174. Passed 12-5-72.)
145.12 OPERATIONS MANAGER.
   (a)   The position of Operations Manager is hereby created.
   (b)   The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor, subject
to the approval of Council, for such period of time and under such conditions
as may be determined at the time of appointment and such appointee shall serve
at the pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 2018-125. Passed 11-20-18.)

CHAPTER 149
Athletic Commission
149.01    Establishment.       
149.02    Application for exhibitions.
149.03    Rules and regulations.
149.04    Fee.
 
   CROSS REFERENCE
Admissions Tax - see ADM. Ch.
191
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3773
 
               
 
149.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established an Athletic Commission, to consist of three
members to be appointed by the Mayor and to serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1964-60. Passed 5-12-64.)
149.02 APPLICATION FOR EXHIBITIONS.
   Applications for boxing and wrestling exhibitions shall be made to the
Athletic Commission. It shall be the duty of the Athletic Commission to make or
cause to be made thorough investigations of all such applications to determine
the financial responsibility and the general character of the applicant, the
fitness of the prospective participants in the boxing or wrestling exhibitions
proposed and such other matters as may be to the granting of the application.
   The Athletic Commission shall report the results of its examinations to the
Mayor with a recommendation whether each such application should be granted or
not.
   The Mayor may grant such permits in accordance with State law. No boxing or
wrestling exhibition shall be held within the City unless authorized by such a
permit, excepting only that this requirement shall not apply in the case of
wrestling exhibitions given in theaters as a regular part of the theater
program.
(Ord. 1964-60. Passed 5-12-64.)
149.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Athletic Commission shall make and may amend, alter or repeal such rules
as it may deem necessary in the public interest to regulate and control the
conditions and conduct of boxing and wrestling exhibitions. The Athletic
Commission may suspend and/or fine any promoter, manager, boxer or wrestler,
pursuant to its rules. The Athletic Commission shall enforce and see to the
enforcement of its rules.
(Ord. 1964-60. Passed 5-12-64.)
149.04 FEE.
   Grantees of permits for professional boxing or wrestling exhibitions shall
pay to the Director of Finance a fee equal to the admissions tax as provided
for in Title Nine, Chapter
191 hereof, and all provisions of such chapter, including exemptions, shall
apply to such fee. (Ord. 1964-60. Passed 5-12-64.)

CHAPTER 153
Records Commission
153.01   Establishment.
153.02   Duties.
153.03   Compensation.
153.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (a)    There is hereby created a Records Commission, pursuant to Section
149.39 of the Ohio Revised Code, composed of the Mayor or the Mayor's appointed
representative, as chairperson, the Director of Finance, the Director of Law,
and a citizen appointed by the Mayor.
   (b)    The citizen appointed by the Mayor shall be a resident of the City,
and serve a term of four (4) years. The Mayor may at any time remove a
commissioner for inefficiency, neglect of duty, misfeasance, nonfeasance or
malfeasance in office, incapacity or incompetency.
   (c)    The Records Commission shall appoint a secretary, who may or may not
be a member of the Records Commission and who shall serve at the pleasure of
the commission.
(Ord. 2017-053. Passed 5-16-17.)
153.02 DUTIES.
   The Records Commission shall provide rules for retention and disposal of
records of the municipal corporation, and to review applications for one-time
disposal of obsolete records and schedules of records retention and disposition
submitted by municipal offices. The Records Commission may dispose of records
pursuant to the procedure outlined in section 149.381 of the Ohio Revised Code.
The Records Commission, at any time, may review any schedule it has previously
approved and, for good cause shown, may revise that schedule under the
procedure outlined in that section. The Records Commission shall meet at least
once every six months and upon the call of the chairperson.
(Ord. 2017-053. Passed 5-16-17.)
153.03 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Records Commission shall serve without compensation unless
otherwise provided by ordinance.
(Ord. 2017-053. Passed 5-16-17.)
                                                                                               
CHAPTER 155
Communications and Activities Department
155.01   Establishment.
155.02   Director.
155.03   Assistant Director of Communications and Activities.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Appointive power of Mayor - see CHTR.
Art. III, §1
155.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Department of Communications and Activities in
and for the City which shall be known as the “Department of Communications and
Activities of the City of Warrensville Heights” or the “Department of
Communications and Activities”.
(Ord. 2016-130. Passed 9-6-16.)
155.02  DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Appointment. The Department of Communications and Activities shall be
administered by a Director who shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to the
confirmation of Council, and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)   Duties.
      (1)   The Director of Communications and Activities is responsible for
maintaining a positive internal and external image of the City. The Director is
responsible for the City’s internal and public communication efforts to educate
and promote the City and its objectives, in addition to interacting with
elected officials, business and community leaders to implement the City’s
communications and activities initiatives. The Director of Communications and
Activities will report directly to the Mayor and Chief of Staff.
      (2)   Duties include, but are not limited to:
         A.   Developing a strategic communications plan that identifies the
City’s current communication barriers and opportunities, and promotes the
City’s strategic messages.
         B.   Creating and executing internal and external communication
campaigns through various types of media platforms including print and
electronic media.
         C.   Working with the Mayor/Chief of Staff to formulate and execute
proactive and reactive communication strategies as needs arise.
         D.   Managing and implementing the City’s day-to-day communications
and media relations, including fielding inquiries about the City, its programs
and events from interested parties.
         E.   Serving as spokesperson for the City for local print interviews
and broadcast appearances when applicable.
      F.   Creating and implementing online communication strategics for the
City with measurable goals, while monitoring and engaging on social media
platforms including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube on behalf of the City.
         G.   Providing an interface between the Mayor’s office and City
departments.
         H.   Attaining measurable publicity goals for the City on specific
projects.
         I.   Conducting public opinion research to assess the City’s
performance.
         J.   Assisting in duties including community event planning and
neighborhood engagement.
         K.   Maintaining archived City communications, current files and
databases.
         L.   Attending required City meetings and assisting with the preparing
of reports and setting of agendas.
         M.   Assisting in the general operations of the Mayor’s office.
   (c)   The duties of the Director of Communications and Activities shall be
to promote community activities and such other duties conferred by the Mayor
and Council.
   (d)   The salary range of the Director of Communications and Activities
shall be prescribed in the periodic comprehensive ordinance establishing the
rate of pay, vacations and medical insurance for municipal department heads and
administrative personnel and employees, with the specific salary to be
determined by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2016-130. Passed 9-6-16.)
155.03 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF COMMUNICATIONS AND ACTIVITIES.
   (a)   Appointment. There is hereby created the position of Assistant
Director of Communications and Activities. The Assistant Director shall be
appointed by the Mayor, upon approval of Council and shall serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)   Duties.
      (1)   The Assistant Director of Communications and Activities is
responsible for helping and maintaining a positive and external image of the
City. The Assistant Director is responsible for assisting in the internal and
public communication efforts to educate and promote the City and its
objectives, which include interacting with elected officials, business and
community leaders to implement the City’s communications and activity
strategies and initiatives. The duties of the Assistant Director of
Communications and Activities shall be to promote community activities and such
other duties conferred by the Mayor, Director and City Council. The Assistant
Director of Communications and Activities will report directly to the Mayor,
Chief of Staff and Director of Communications and Activities.
      (2)   Duties include, but are not limited to:
         A.   Assisting with the development of a strategic communications plan
that identifies the City’s current communications barriers and opportunities
and promotes the City’s strategic messages.
         B.   Assisting with the creation and execution of internal and
external campaigns through various types of media platforms including print and
electronic media.
         C.   Working with the Mayor/Chief of Staff/Director of Communications
and Activities to formulate and execute proactive and reactive communication
strategies as needs arise.
         D.   Assisting with the management and implementation of the City’s
day-to-day communications and media relations, including fielding inquiries
about the City, its programs and events from interested parties.
         E.   Serving as spokesperson for the City for local print interviews
and broadcast appearances when applicable.
         F.   Assisting with the creation and implementation of the online
communication strategies for the City with measurable goals while monitoring
and engaging on social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, and
YouTube on behalf of the City.
         G.   Assisting in providing an interface between the Mayor’s office
and City departments.
         H.   Attaining measurable publicity goals for the City on specific
projects.
         I.   Conducting public opinion research to assess the City’s
performance.
         J.   Assisting in duties including community event planning and
neighborhood engagement.
         K.   Attending required City meetings and assisting with the
preparation of reports and setting of agendas.
         L.   Assisting in the general operations of the Mayor’s office.
   (c)   The salary range of the Assistant Director of Communications and
Activities shall be prescribed in the periodic comprehensive ordinance
establishing the rate of pay, vacations and medical insurance for municipal
department heads and administrative personnel and employees, with the specific
salary to be determined by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2016-130. Passed 9-6-16.)

CHAPTER 163
Civil Defense
163.01    Organization created.
163.02    Appointment.
163.03    Duties and functions.
163.04    Compensation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Civil defense - see Ohio R.C. 5915.01 et seq.
 
 
 
163.01 ORGANIZATION CREATED.
   There is hereby created the civil defense organization for the City as an
agency of such government, to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from natural disaster or enemy attack.
(Ord. 1973-141. Passed 12-18-73.)
163.02 APPOINTMENT.
   This civil defense organization shall consist of the Director of Disaster
Services and additional members to be appointed by the Director. All officers
and employees of this City are declared to be members of the organization,
together with those volunteer forces appointed to aid them during a disaster.
   The Director shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall serve until removed
by the same. The Director shall coordinate the organization, administration,
planning and operations of all local agencies for civil defense, subject to the
direction and control of the Mayor as provided by statute.
(Ord. 1973-141. Passed 12-18-73.)
163.03 DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS.
   The civil defense organization shall perform such functions within the
Municipality as shall be prescribed in and authorized by Ohio R.C. Chapter 5915
and the Governor's Regulations for Civil Defense, and in addition shall perform
such duties outside the corporate limits as shall be required pursuant to
mutual aid arrangements with any other political subdivision or with the
country-wide civil defense organization. In performing duties pursuant to this
chapter, the Director of Disaster Services shall cooperate with other political
subdivisions, with the country-wide organization for civil defense, with the
State of Ohio and with the Federal government through appropriate channels, and
with private agencies, in all matters pertaining to the civil defense
activities of the City.
(Ord. 1973-141. Passed 12-18-73.)
163.04 COMPENSATION.
   The Director of Disaster Services and other civil defense personnel
appointed or assigned as herein provided, shall receive such compensation as
may be provided for by Council.
(Ord. 1973-141. Passed 12-18-73.)

CHAPTER 167
Employees Generally
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Because it is subject to frequent change, salary and fringe
benefit legislation is not included in these Codified Ordinances. Interested
parties are advised to consult the Director of Finance for information
pertaining to such legislation currently in effect.
167.01   Vacations and holidays for full-time appointed salaried employees.
167.02   Payment for temporary employment.
167.03   Hours rate compensation.
167.04   Annual salary review.
167.05   Pay period.
167.06   Determination of employee’s actual compensation rate.
167.07   Medical insurance and other benefits.
167.08   Sick leave.
167.09   Funeral leave.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Civil Service Commission - see CHTR. Art. V,
§9
Classified service - see CHTR. Art. V,
 §9(c)
Political activity of employees - see CHTR. Art. V,
§9(g)
Legal holidays - see Ohio R.C. 5.20 et seq.
Sick leave - see Ohio R.C. 124.38
 
 
 
167.01 VACATIONS AND HOLIDAYS FOR FULL-TIME APPOINTED SALARIED EMPLOYEES.
   Any and all full-time appointed officials or employees of the City who
receive compensation on a regular established salary basis, shall be granted
vacations with full regular pay as follows, and subject to the following
regulations:
   (a)   No person shall be considered as a full-time official or employee or
eligible for vacations under this chapter unless such person serves a minimum
of at least thirty- five hours per week in the service of the City.
      (Ord. 1970-67. Passed 5-6-70.)
   (b)   In computing the vacation leave to be allotted to employees, the
anniversary date of the initial employment of the employee shall be used to
determine the vacation leave to which an employee is entitled annually.
Notwithstanding the provisions of Ohio R.C. 9.44 (or any successor section),
vacation time shall be calculated solely and exclusively on the basis of
service with the City of Warrensville Heights. Said calculation shall begin
from the date of initial service with the City of Warrensville Heights.
Previous service with any other public employer or public entity shall not be
credited as service time for purposes of the calculation of vacation leave. The
maximum number of vacation leave hours that an employee may accumulate shall
not exceed 336 hours, except when the employee’s department head certifies to
the Mayor, in writing, that the employee has exceeded the maximum as a result
of the City’s inability to allow the employee to take paid vacation leave due
to staffing requirements. However, upon separation from the City of
Warrensville Heights by retirement or otherwise, the maximum number of vacation
leave hours for which an employee may receive payment shall be 336 hours.
      (Ord. 2003-121. Passed 9-16-03.)
   (c)   Regular compensation shall be provided to administrative employees who
work at least 35 hours per week for the following holidays observed by the
City: New Year’s Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Presidents’ Day, Good
Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Day after
Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, Juneteenth, and the Employee’s
birthday. However, the observed holidays shall not be accumulated in any
manner.
      (Ord. 2023-120. Passed 11-8-23.)
   (d)   Vacation time may be cumulative from one year to the next, provided
that such cumulative vacation time does not exceed forty-two days.
   (e)   No vacation shall be granted without the approval of the Mayor and the
head of the department involved, and all vacations shall be taken and granted
according to such schedules as may be established by the Mayor and the heads of
various departments involved. Preference for dates on such schedule shall be
granted according to the seniority of the official or employee.
      (Ord. 1970-67. Passed 5-6-70.)
   (f)   Vacations for full-time appointed, salaried and hourly administration
employees not governed by a collective bargaining agreement shall be granted in
the following manner:
      (1)   Eighty hours of vacation after the first year of completed service
through three years of completed service.
      (2)   One hundred twenty hours of vacation after four years of completed
service through seven years of completed service.
      (3)   Four weeks vacation after eight years of completed service through
fourteen years of completed service.
      (4)   Five weeks of vacation after fifteen or more years of completed
service.
         (Ord. 2003-123. Passed 9-16-03.)
167.02 PAYMENT FOR TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT.
   Any temporary employment made necessary because of granting of vacation
periods as provided for herein shall be payable from the appropriate funds of
the Municipality.
(Ord. 1950-35. Passed 5-17-50.)
167.03 HOURLY RATE COMPUTATION.
   Pay for such vacation period shall be computed at the hourly rate to which
such person is entitled as compensation for employment by the Municipality
multiplied by forty.
(Ord. 1968-89. Passed 5-21-68.)
167.04 ANNUAL SALARY REVIEW.
   Wages and salaries for all administrative employees not covered by a
collective bargaining unit shall be reviewed on an annual basis and any changes
shall become effective for such employees on January 1.
(Ord. 2003-125. Passed 9-16-03.)
167.05 PAY PERIOD.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to pay all Municipal employees
on a biweekly basis commencing January 1, 1969.
(Ord. 1968-217. Passed 12-3-68.)
167.06 DETERMINATION OF EMPLOYEE’S ACTUAL COMPENSATION RATE.
   The Mayor shall set the actual rate of compensation for each employee. Said
rate of compensation shall be set within the minimum and maximum range for the
employee’s position as set forth in the annual salary and wage ordinance.
(Ord. 2003-120. Passed 9-16-03.)
167.07 MEDICAL INSURANCE AND OTHER BENEFITS.
   (a)   Medical insurance and other benefits shall be available to City
employees under the terms and conditions determined by the Mayor with the
approval of City Council.
   (b)   City Council members shall have the option of participating in the
health insurance program provided by the City of Warrensville Heights if there
is no other Health Insurance Program available to the City Council official (i)
through his or her employer or (ii) his or her spouse. The participating
Council member shall bear twenty percent (20%) of the total cost of the premium
associated with participation in the Plan.
   (c)   Members of Council who request coverage under the City’s medical
insurance plan shall be granted such coverage to be comprised of the following:
      (1)   Basic medical and major medical coverage for the Councilperson and
eligible dependents;
      (2)   Dental coverage for the Councilperson and eligible dependents; and
      (3)   Vision care plans for the Councilperson and eligible dependents.
         (Ord. 2013-119. Passed 12-17-13.)
167.08 SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   After six (6) months of continuous service, with the City of
Warrensville Heights, each full time administrative employee shall receive a
credit of forty hours of paid sick leave and shall continue to accrue sick
leave at a rate of four and sixty-hundredths (4.62) hours per bi-weekly pay
period up to a maximum of 120 hours annually. In accordance with the Ohio
Revised Code, prior public service sick leave may be transferred upon
employment with the City of Warrensville Heights up to 2080 hours. Employees
not governed by a collective bargaining agreement may accumulate an unlimited
amount of sick leave and shall be entitled to use sick leave for their illness
or the illness of a qualifying family member provided the employee can provide
medical documentation which is satisfactory to the department head and the
Mayor.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the unlimited accumulation of sick leave provided for
in subsection (a) hereof, upon separation from the City of Warrensville Heights
by service or disability or retirement, with no less than ten (10) years of
public service, an employee may receive payment for 25% of unused sick leave
earned and accumulated during employment with the City up to a maximum payment
of 30 days or 240 hours of such unused sick leave. Upon separation from the
City by means other than retirement with less than ten (10) years of public
service and/or accumulated unused sick leave of less than 120 days or 960
hours, an employee may request to transfer the remaining balance to another
public employer, or receive payment of 25% of the remaining unused sick leave
balance earned and accumulated during employment with the City up to a maximum
of 30 days or 240 hours. For clarification, an employee separated from the City
for any reason, including service, disability, termination or retirement, shall
only receive payment of 25% of unused sick leave that was earned and
accumulated during employment with the City and not for unused sick leave
transferred to the City pursuant to subsection (a) above.
(Ord. 2018-023. Passed 3-6-18.)
167.09 FUNERAL LEAVE.
   After six (6) months of continuous service with the City of Warrensville
Heights, an employee may utilize up to three (3) consecutive workdays, with
pay, for the purpose of attending the funeral of the employee’s mother, father,
father-in-law or mother-in-law, child, spouse, brother, sister, brother-in-law,
sister-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, grandfather, grandmother,
grandchildren, stepparent or stepchild. The employee shall furnish proof,
satisfactory to the employee’s department head and the Mayor, of death and
relationship of the deceased upon written application for the foregoing leave
authorization. In a City located more than one hundred fifty (150) miles from
Warrensville Heights, the employee may utilize an additional two (2)
consecutive scheduled days’ leave for travel for the above family member
deaths.
(Ord. 2003-132. Passed 10-7-03.)
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 169
Legal Defense and Indemnification
169.01    Legal defense and costs.
169.02    Conflict of interest.
169.03    Indemnify and save harmless.
169.04    Conditions.
169.05    Workers' compensation.
169.06    Other insurance.
169.07    Immunity.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. 9.87
 
 
 
169.01 LEGAL DEFENSE AND COSTS.
   (a)    Upon compliance by the public official or public employee with the
provisions of this chapter, the City shall provide the legal defense and costs
of the public official or public employee in any civil action or proceeding
arising out of any alleged act or omission which occurred or allegedly occurred
while the public official or public employee was acting within the scope of his
public employment or duties.
   (b)    The duty to provide for a defense shall not arise where such civil
action or proceeding is brought by or at the request of the City against the
public official or public employee.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.02 CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   Subject to the conditions set forth in this chapter, the public official or
public employee shall be entitled to be represented by the City Law Department
and in the event it is determined that a conflict of interest would exist in
the representation of the public official or public employee by the City Law
Department, then the public official or public employee is entitled to be
represented by counsel of his choice, provided, that such counsel is approved
by Council and in no event shall private counsel be entitled to a rate in
excess of the rate that the City provides its Chief Legal Counsel at that time.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.03 INDEMNIFY AND SAVE HARMLESS.
   The City shall indemnify and save harmless its public officials or public
employees in the amount of any judgment obtained against such public officials
or public employees or in the amount of any settlement of a claim provided that
the act or omission from which such judgment or claim arose occurred while the
public official or public employee was acting, within the scope of his public
employment duties, provided further that in the case of a settlement the duty
to indemnify and save harmless shall be conditioned upon the approval of the
amount of the settlement by Council.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.04 CONDITIONS.
   The duty to defend or indemnify and save harmless prescribed by this chapter
shall be conditioned upon:
   (a)    Delivery by the public official or public employee to the Mayor a
written request to provide for his or her defense together with the original or
a copy of any summons, complaint, process, notice, demand or pleading within
five days after he or she is served with such document.
   (b)    The full cooperation of the public official or public employee in the
defense of such action or proceeding and in defense of any action or proceeding
against the City based upon the same act or omission and in the prosecution of
any appeal. (Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.05 WORKERS' COMPENSATION.
   The benefits of this chapter shall not be construed to affect, alter or
repeal any section of the workers' compensation law.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.06 OTHER INSURANCE.
   (a)    The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to impair,
alter, limit or modify the rights and obligations of the City, public official
or public employee under any policy of insurance they may have.
   (b)    The benefits provided by this chapter shall not apply when the public
official or public employee is provided with insurance coverage by the City
save and except those items of expense or damage not covered by insurance
including losses that would be incurred under deductible provisions of
insurance policies.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
169.07 IMMUNITY.
   (a)    The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed in any way to
impair, alter, limit, modify, abrogate or restrict any immunity to liability
available to the City, public official or public employee or any other benefit
provided by statutory or common law to the City, public official or public
employee.
   (b)    The benefits provided under this chapter shall apply whether or not
the public official or public employee is sued in an individual or
representative capacity and whether or not the public official or public
employee is still in office or employed by the City, provided, however, that
the acts complained of were committed during the course of and as a result of
his public employment.
(Ord. 1982-32. Passed 4-20-82.)
 
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 179
