179.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Department of Civic and Senior Affairs in and
for the City which shall be known as “The Department of Civic and Senior
Affairs of the City of Warrensville Heights” or “The Department of Civic and
Senior Affairs”.
(11-19-91)
179.02 DIRECTOR.
   The Department of Civic and Senior Affairs shall be headed by a Director who
shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of Council. The position of
Director of the Department of Civic and Senior Affairs shall be full-time as
defined in Section
167.01, and the Director of Civic and Senior Affairs shall serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor.
(11-19-91)
179.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director of Civic and Senior Affairs shall supervise the development,
implementation and management of programs for City residents and the City’s
civic and cultural groups in conjunction with the operation of the City’s
Civic/Senior Center. Subject to the direction and approval of the Mayor, the
Director shall:
   (a)   Oversee all functions at the Civic/Senior Center for residents of all
age groups.
   (b)   Develop and implement programs for the participation and enjoyment of
City residents.
   (c)   Develop and implement programs that deal with the needs of specific
groups within the City, such as needs of the elderly and young people of the
City.
   (d)   Direct or bring together individuals willing to donate their time or
services in helping others within the City.
   (e)   Such other duties as the Mayor may assign and prescribe for the
office.
      (11-19-91)
179.04 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR.
   The position of Assistant Director of the Department of Civic and Senior
Affairs for the City of Warrensville Heights is hereby created. The position of
Assistant Director shall be full- time as defined in Section
167.01.
   (a)   The appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor and said
Assistant Director shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)   The Assistant Director shall perform such duties as the Mayor and
Director of Civic and Senior Affairs shall assign and prescribe for the office.
      (11-19-91)
179.05 SALARY OF DIRECTOR AND ASSISTANT DIRECTOR.
   The salary range of the Director of Civic and Senior Affairs and the
Assistant Director of Civic and Senior Affairs shall be prescribed in the
periodic comprehensive ordinance establishing the rate of pay, vacations and
medical insurance for municipal department heads and administrative personnel
and employees, with the specific salary to be determined by the Mayor. (11-19-
91)
179.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Civic and Senior Affairs shall promulgate rules and
regulations with respect to the use of the Civic/Senior Center, subject to the
approval of the Mayor, which shall be consistent with the purpose and intent of
the powers and duties set forth in this chapter.
(11-19-91)
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 180
Chief of Staff
180.01   Position created.
180.02   Duties.
180.03   Salary.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR. Art. V,
Sec. 2
 
 
 
180.01 POSITION CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of Chief of Staff. The Chief of Staff
shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of Council, and shall serve
at the pleasure of the Mayor. The Chief of Staff shall be a full-time position
as defined in Section
167.01.
(Ord. 1994-95. Passed 10-4-94; Ord. 2000-01. Passed 1-18-00.)
180.02 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Chief of Staff shall be such as the Mayor may, from time
to time, direct and shall include, but not be limited to the following:
   (a)   The Chief of Staff shall review all county, state and federal programs
for which the City may be eligible to receive funds.
   (b)   The Chief of Staff shall oversee the preparation of all applications
for funds or grants for which the City may be eligible.
   (c)   The Chief of Staff shall monitor the City’s compliance with all state
and federal regulatory programs, including but not limited to the Americans
with Disabilities Act, the Family Medical Leave Act, the Consolidated Omnibus
Budget Reconciliation Act (“COBRA”) and federal occupational and safety
requirements.
   (d)   The Chief of Staff shall receive applications for and oversee
compliance of applicants with the requirements for tax abatement under the
City’s Community Reinvestment Program.
   (e)   The Chief of Staff shall prepare protocols for each municipal
department.
   (f)   The Chief of Staff shall monitor the City’s compliance with the
requirements of the Ohio Historical Society in regard to the disposition of
City records.
   (g)   The Chief of Staff shall formulate recommendations and proposals to
maximize the efficiency of each municipal department.
   (h)   The Chief of Staff shall issue periodic reports in regard to the
condition and maintenance of municipal facilities.
   (i)   The Chief of Staff shall update rules and regulations of each
municipal department.
   (j)   The Chief of Staff shall design and implement the use of uniform City
applications and forms.
   (k)   The Chief of Staff shall facilitate and supervise interdepartmental
activities as required to implement the duties of this chapter.
   (l)   The Chief of Staff shall perform such other duties as the Mayor may
assign and prescribe for the office.
   (m)   The Chief of Staff shall do any and all things necessary and proper to
carry out the duties prescribed pursuant to this chapter.
      (Ord. 1994-95. Passed 10-4-94; Ord. 2000-01. Passed 1-18-00.)
180.03 SALARY.
   The Chief of Staff shall receive compensation as provided by ordinance.
(Ord. 1994-95. Passed 10-4-94; Ord. 2000-01. Passed 1-18-00.)
                                                                                                   
CHAPTER 182
Community and Economic Development Department
182.01   Establishment.
182.02   Director.
182.03   Community Development Manager.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR. Art. V, Sec.
2
 
 
 
182.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Department of Community and Economic
Development in and for the City which shall be known as the “Department of
Community and Economic Development of the City of Warrensville Heights” or the
“Department of Community and Economic Development”.
(Ord. 2005-122. Passed 7-19-05.)
182.02 DIRECTOR.
      (a)    Appointment. The Department of Community and Economic Development
shall be administered by a Director who shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to the confirmation of Council. The position of Director of Community
and Economic Development shall be a full-time position as defined in Section
167.01, and the Director of the Department of Community and Economic
Development shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)    Powers and Duties. The Director of the Department of Community and
Economic Development shall supervise the development, implementation and
management of all programs and policies designed to maintain, create and
promote increased community and economic development in the City. Subject to
the direction and approval of the Mayor, the Director shall:
      (1)   Develop and implement programs designed to encourage existing
businesses in the City to remain in the City.
      (2)   Develop and implement programs designed to encourage additional
business and commercial development in the City.
      (3)   Establish a budget for the Department.
      (4)   Prepare and/or supervise the preparation of all applications for
federal, state and county grant funds which may be available to the City.
      (5)   Develop and implement programs designed to obtain grants and/or
loans which may be available for the betterment of the residents of the City.
      (6)   Seek all available funding for the improvement of the residential,
retail, commercial and industrial areas of the City.
      (7)   Perform such other duties as the Mayor may assign and prescribe for
this office.
      (8)   Review all aspects of community oriented issues directed to him/her
and report and make recommendations directly to the Mayor.
      (9)   Provide advice and opinions relative to City activities.
      (10)   Coordinate interdepartmental activities of the City.
      (11)   Promote the City and its achievements.
      (12)   Promote good will for the community.
      (13)   Do any and all things necessary and proper to carry out the above.
   (c)    Salary. The Director of Community and Economic Development shall
receive compensation as provided by ordinance. (Ord. 2015-158. Passed 12-15-
15.)
182.03 COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT MANAGER.
   (a)    Establishment. There is hereby established the position of Community
Development Manager.
  
   (b)    Appointment.  The Community Development Manager shall be appointed by
the Mayor, subject to the confirmation of Council. The position of Community
Development Manager shall be a full-time position as defined in Section
167.01, and the Community Development Manager shall serve at the pleasure of
the Mayor.
   (c)    Powers and Duties.  The Community Development Manager shall plan and
organize the implementation of projects, administer community development
activities, coordinate the implementation of public facility improvements,
public services and other related programs, and interface with the Building and
Finance Departments, which includes current and long-range planning, finance
coordination, code enforcement and real estate and lands activities. Subject to
the direction and approval of the Mayor, the Community Development Manager
shall:
      (1)   Assist with preparing and administering budgets.
      (2)   Assist with planning the program of work for the Department.
      (3)   Determine work procedures, prepare work schedules and expedite
workflow.
      (4)   Examine work for accuracy and compliance with policies and
procedures.
      (5)   Study and standardize procedures to improve efficiency of
subordinates.
      (6)   Maintain harmony among workers and resolve grievances.
      (7)   Prepare composite reports from individual reports of subordinates.
      (8)   Adjust errors and resolve complaints.
      (9)   Prepare and document budget requests.
      (10)   Administer adopted budget in the Department.
      (11)   Determine applicable codes, regulations and requirements for
assigned projects.
      (12)   Review private project development plans for compliance with
codes, regulations and standands, adequacy of applications for permits and
compliance with approved plans.
      (13)   Coordinate and/or undertake the development or update plans
involving the municipal infrastructure.
      (14)   Coordinate the preparation of, or develop, engineering plans and
specifications, coordinate required advertising for bids, review construction
bids and make necessary recommendations based on lowest and best bids,
competency of vendors and consultants and the selection criteria.
      (15)   Provide project management for the construction of the municipal
public works projects.
      (16)   Oversee assigned projects to ensure contractor compliance with
time and budget parameters for the project.
      (17)   Coordinate the preparation of, or develop, review and update the
sanitary sewer, water, storm drainage and street system maps, databases and
comprehensive plans.
      (18)   Maintain the assigned library and infrastructure records.
      (19)   Maintain City subdivision and public works standards.
      (20)   Review records of projects and document necessary changes for the
operation and maintenance programs.
      (21)   Be responsible for the Community Reinvestment Area (CRA)
Residential Program, City Foodbank Program and similar like programs.
      (22)   Respond to public or other inquiries relative to engineering
procedures on specific projects and other information.
      (23)   Evaluate issues and options regarding municipal public works and
make recommendations.
      (24)    Review utility permits, street use permits, franchise utility
permits, etc.
      (25)   Maintain regular contact with consulting engineers, construction
project engineers, city, county, state and federal agencies, professional and
technical groups, and the general public regarding division activities and
services.
      (26)   Assist in the evaluation of transportation and traffic impact of
development proposals, permits, rezones, plats, etc.
      (27)   Prepare traffic, utility and other studies and reports.
      (28)   Provide intersection signal and channelization design.
      (29)   Develop and maintain a pavement management system.
      (30)   Review private project development plans for compliance with
codes, regulations and standards, adequacy of applications for permits and
compliance with approved plans.
      (31)   Assist subordinates with performing duties, as needed.
   (d)    Salary. The Community Development Manager shall receive compensation
as provided by ordinance. (Ord. 2015-158. Passed 12-15-15.)

Senior Advocacy Liaison Director

183.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
      There is hereby established the position of Senior Advocacy Liaison
Director.
(Ord. 2015-156. Passed 12-15-15.)
183.02 APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   The Senior Advocacy Liaison Director shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to the confirmation of Council. The position of Senior Advocacy Liaison
Director shall be a full-time position as defined in Section
167.01, and the Senior Advocacy Liaison Director shall serve at the pleasure of
the Mayor. (Ord. 2015-156. Passed 12-15-15.)
183.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Senior Advocacy Liaison Director shall provide leadership for the
delivery of services and support that will improve and promote the quality of
life and personal choice for older Ohioans, and their families and caregivers.
Subject to the direction and approval of the Mayor, the Senior Advocacy Liaison
Director shall:
   (a)   Plan, develop, direct, administer and evaluate multiple statewide
human services programs and procedures.
   (b)   Implement outreach strategies for internal and external stakeholders
interested in programs directed for the City residents with programming,
services and activities.
   (c)   Identify and nurture strategic partnerships; work with state and local
governments, institutions of higher education and private employers to
incorporate aging Ohioans' needs into plans, policies and services.
   (d)   Establish and maintain effective collaborative working relationships
with leadership and program staff in partner agencies.
   (e)   Act as liaison with community and/or governmental officials and
representatives; attend seminars, conferences and meetings.
   (f)   Develop programs and establish partnerships to promote healthy aging.
   (g)   Give attention to duties in a timely manner.
      (Ord. 2015-156. Passed 12-15-15.)
183.04 SALARY.
   The Senior Advocacy Liaison Director shall receive compensation as provided
by ordinance.
(Ord. 2015-156. Passed 12-15-15.)
CHAPTER 184
Director of Strategic Initiatives
184.01   Establishment.
184.02   Appointment; term.
184.03   Powers and duties of Director.
184.04   Salary.
184.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
      There is hereby established the position of Director of Strategic
Initiatives.
(Ord. 2016-005. Passed 1-5-16.)
184.02 APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   The Director of Strategic Initiatives shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to the confirmation of Council. The position of Director of Strategic
Initiatives shall be a full-time position as defined in Section
167.01, and the Director of Strategic Initiatives shall serve at the pleasure
of the Mayor. (Ord. 2016-005. Passed 1-5-16.)
184.03  POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   The Director of Strategic Initiatives under the direction of the Mayor and
in coordination with the Chief of Staff shall help to identify, investigate,
and assess community needs, formulate creative strategies to address them
through the development of significant projects, programs and collaborations
using various available resources, be responsible for helping to advance the
City's vision on an approach to education, serve as a liaison between the City
and the Warrensville Heights School District (the "District"), be instrumental
in strategic planning and implementation of the same for key organizational
initiatives for the District and various City departmental Directors, and
research and report on impactful projects, programs, and collaborations that
are/will benefit the City. Subject to the direction and approval of the Mayor,
the Director of Strategic Initiatives shall:
   (a)   Lead selected program based special projects that require cross-
functional engagement with key staff across the organization and with external
supports.
   (b)   Coordinate the District in federal, state, and special programs.
Collaborate with staff and outside personnel to formulate, develop, implement,
and evaluate federal, state and special programs.
   (c)   Research, identify, profile and develop new partnerships and expand
existing partnerships based on fit and alignment with the City's growth
strategy and program vision.
   (d)   Proactively reach out to potential partners to understand
opportunities for collaboration with ability to effectively manage twenty to
thirty (20 - 30) partner opportunities in various stages in the pipeline.
   (e)   Have the ability to understand and articulate the strategic direction
of new and existing partners' business models, needs and advantages and
alignment to the vision and direction of the City and the District, and
articulate the City's overall value proposition, solutions and services.
   (f)   Work cross functionally with City internal operations, management and
marketing teams.
   (g)   Track and report partner performance on an on-going basis
   (h)   Work with the District's Superintendent or designee, the City's Chief
of Staff and Community and Economic Development Director on strategy and best
practices to assess, engage and develop new partnerships.
   (i)   Oversee execution of a network of partnership services within the
District in collaboration with the District's leadership.
   (j)   Develop and nurture positive relationships with the District's
administrators and relevant community agencies to optimize the partnership.
   (k)   Participate in strategic planning with the District and community
stakeholders; identify, develop and implement programming that supports the
collective vision of the District; outline and promote service direction.
   (l)   Identify and recruit external program partners and organizations that
aim to increase educational opportunities and social connections for the
students of the District.
   (m)   Oversee that the external partnerships meets all City licensing,
security, contractual, quality management and outcome standards and
requirements.
   (n)   Develop and regularly monitor the budget of each funding source and
corresponding service array.
   (o)   Coordinate billing and budgeting with the Finance Department when
applicable.
   (p)   Represent the City at pertinent meetings and functions which may be
held during evenings, weekends or holidays as directed by the Mayor or Chief of
Staff.
   (q)   Participate in fundraising and grant writing activities.
      (Ord. 2016-005. Passed 1-5-16.)
184.04 SALARY.
   The Director of Strategic Initiatives shall receive compensation as provided
by ordinance.
(Ord. 2016-005. Passed 1-5-16.)

Admissions Tax

191.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Admission charge” means the charge made by a place as defined in
subsection (b) hereof, for the right or privilege of entering into such place
and/or for the right or privilege of using any of the facilities of such place,
and shall include all charges therefor whether denominated an admission charge
or denominated cover charge or word or words of similar import. It shall also
include a charge made for rental or use of equipment or facilities for purposes
of recreation or amusement and a charge made and collected by the deposit of a
coin into a machine or mechanical device, which machine thereby permits a
person or operator to play a game or try the skill of the operator or person
using such machine or which mechanical device thereby causes any person or
operator to secure amusement, enjoyment or relaxation by its use. If more than
one type of charge is made for the aforementioned rights and privileges, then
the admission charge shall be the combined total of such charges.
   (b)   “Place” means any enterprise permitted, conducted or operated by a
person, as defined by subsection (c) hereof, for which there is an admission
charge. Examples of places, but not limited to the following are theaters,
dance halls, amphitheaters, museums, auditoriums, stadiums, skating rinks,
athletic pavilions and fields, parks, circuses, side shows, swimming
facilities, tennis facilities, tennis courts, tennis clubs, paddle tennis
courts, paddle tennis clubs, handball clubs, handball courts, squash courts,
squash clubs, golf facilities, golf driving range, fairway or putting practice
facilities, outdoor amusement parks and rides and observation towers, bowling
alleys and places that have mechanical game devices. A club that provides any
of the foregoing shall be deemed a “place”.
   (c)   “Person” means any individual, receiver, assignee, firm, co-
partnership, joint venture, corporation, company, joint stock company,
association, society, or any group of persons acting as a unit, whether mutual,
cooperative, fraternal, nonprofit or otherwise.
      (Ord. 1981-103. Passed 12-15-81.)
191.02 ADMISSIONS TAX.
   There is levied and imposed upon every person who pays an admission charge
to any place, including a tax on persons who are admitted free of charge or at
reduced rates, for which other persons pay a charge or a regular higher charge
for the same or similar privileges or accommodations:
   (a)   A tax of ten percent (10%) on the amount received as an admission
charge to any place. The tax shall apply to every admission within the
Municipality.
   (b)   A tax of ten percent (10%) on excess of the amount received for
tickets or cards of admission to theaters, operas and other places of
amusement, sold at a location other than the ticket offices of such places,
over and above the amounts representing the established admission charge
therefor at such ticket offices, such tax to be returned and paid in the manner
provided in Section
191.04 by the person selling the ticket.
   (c)   A tax of ten percent (10%) on the admission charge to any public
performance for profit.
   (d)   A tax of ten percent (10%) on the admission charge received as annual
membership dues by every club or organization maintaining a place as defined by
Section
191.01(b).
   (e)   A tax of ten percent (10%) on the amount received, exclusive of
federal, State and local admission taxes, for or on account of the use of any
place for a public performance, the admission charge to which performance is
exempt from tax under Section
191.03, such tax to be applicable regardless of whether such receipts are
designated by the owner, operator or lessee of such place as rentals of
property, charges for talent or services or otherwise.
      (Ord. 2001-27. Passed 5-1-01.)
191.03 ADMISSIONS EXEMPT FROM TAX.
   No tax shall be levied under this chapter with respect to any admission
charge, all the net proceeds of which inure:
   (a)    Exclusively to the benefit of religious, educational or charitable
institutions, societies or organizations, if no part of the net earnings
thereof inure to the benefit of any private stockholder or individual.
   (b)    Exclusively to the benefit of persons in the military or naval forces
of the United States, or of National Guard organizations, reserve officer
associations or posts or organizations of war veterans, or auxiliary units or
societies of any such posts or organizations if such posts, organizations,
units or societies are organized in the State of Ohio, and if no part of their
net earnings inure to the benefit of any private stockholder or individual.
   (c)    Exclusively to the benefit of persons who serve in the military or
naval forces of the United States and are in need.
   (d)    Exclusively to the benefit of members of any department of any
municipal corporation, or the dependents or heirs of such members.
   (e)    Exclusively to the benefit of the general revenue fund of any
municipal corporation or exclusively to the benefit of any fund of any
municipal corporation under the control of a recreation commission.
   (f)    Immediately after the event for which an exemption from admission tax
has been allowed, the treasurer of the institution, society or organization for
whose benefit such event was held shall file an itemized statement with the
Director of Finance setting forth the amount of money actually received by such
treasurer together with the expenses of promoting and conducting such event.
Such statement shall be used as a basis of subsequent requests for exemption
from admissions tax for the benefit of such institution, society or
organization and if such statement shows a disproportionate expenditure for
promoting and conducting of such event in relation to the profits, if any, no
such exemption shall thereafter be allowed to such institution, society or
organization.
   (g)    The exemption from tax provided in this section shall not be allowed
to any institution, society or organization which does not control the sale of
admissions to the event for which the exemption is requested, nor shall any
exemption be allowed where talent, services of other items are compensated for
on a percentage basis if such percentage results in a payment in excess of the
flat rate ordinarily charged for the same talent, services or other items.
      (Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.04 COLLECTION OF TAX.
   Every person receiving any payment on which a tax is levied under this
chapter shall collect the amount of the tax imposed from the person making the
admission payment. The tax required to be collected under this chapter shall be
deemed to be held in trust by the person required to collect the same until
paid to the Director of Finance as herein provided. Any person required to
collect the tax imposed under this chapter who fails to collect the same, or
having collected the same, fails to remit the same to the Director of Finance
in the manner prescribed by this chapter, whether such failure be the result of
acts or conditions beyond his control, shall nevertheless be personally liable
to the Municipality for the amount of such tax, and shall, unless the
remittance be made as herein required, be guilty of a violation of this
chapter. The tax imposed hereunder shall be collected at the time the admission
charge is paid by the person seeking admission to any place and shall be
reported and remitted by the person receiving the tax to the Director in
monthly installments and remittances therefor on or before the thirtieth day of
the month succeeding the end of the monthly period in which the tax is
collected or received. Payment or remittance of the tax collected may be made
by check, unless payment or remittance is otherwise required by the Director,
but payment by check shall not relieve the person collecting the tax from
liability for payment and remittance of the tax to the Director unless the
check is honored and is in the full and correct amount. The person receiving
any payment for admissions shall make out a return upon such forms and setting
forth such information as the Director may require, showing the amount of the
tax upon admissions for which he is liable for the preceding monthly period,
and shall sign and transmit the same to the Director with a remittance for such
amount; provided, that the Director may in his discretion require verified
annual returns from any person receiving admission payments setting forth such
additional information as he may deem necessary to determine correctly the
amount of tax collected and payable. Whenever any theater, circus, show,
exhibition, entertainment or amusement makes an admission charge which is
subject to the tax herein levied, and the same is of a temporary or transitory
nature, of which the Director shall be the judge, the Director may require the
report and remittance of the admission tax immediately upon the collection of
the same, at the conclusion of the performance or exhibition, or at the
conclusion of the series of performances or exhibitions or at such other times
as the Director shall determine; and failure to comply with any requirement of
the Director as to report and remittance of the tax as required shall be a
violation of this chapter. The books, records and accounts of any person
collecting a tax herein levied shall, as to admission charges and tax
collections, be at all reasonable times subject to examination and audit by the
Director. If the tax imposed by this chapter is not paid when due there shall
be added, as part of the tax, interest at the rate of one percent per month
from the time when the tax became due until paid.
(Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.05 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   Any person conducting or operating any place for entrance to which an
admission charge is made shall, on the form prescribed by the Director of
Finance, make application to and procure from the Director a Certificate of
Registration, the fee for which shall be ten dollars ($10.00), which
Certificate shall continue valid until December 31 of the year in which the
same is issued. Such Certificate of Registration, or duplicate original copies
thereof to be issued by the Director without additional charge, shall be posted
in a conspicuous place in each ticket or box office where tickets of admission
are sold.
(Ord. 1978-188. Passed 12-19-78.)
191.06 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION IN CASE OF TEMPORARY OR TRANSITORY
AMUSEMENT.
   Whenever a Certificate of Registration is obtained for the purpose of
operating or conducting a temporary or transitory amusement, entertainment or
exhibition by persons who are not the owners, lessees or custodians of the
building, lots or place where the amusement is to be conducted, the tax imposed
by this chapter shall be reported and remitted as provided in Section
191.04 hereof by such owner, lessee or custodian, unless paid by the person
conducting the place. The applicant for a Certificate of Registration for such
purpose shall furnish with the application therefor the name and address of the
owner, lessee or custodian of the premises upon which the amusement is to be
conducted, and such owner, lessee or custodian shall be notified by the
Director of Finance of the issuance of such certificate and the joint liability
for collection and remittance of such tax.
(Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.07 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor or Director of Finance shall have power to adopt rules and
regulations not inconsistent with the terms of this chapter for carrying out
and enforcing the payment, collection and remittance of the tax herein levied;
and a copy of such rules and regulations shall be published as ordinances of
the Municipality are published before they become effective, and copies shall
be made available in the office of the Director of Finance. Failure or refusal
to comply with any such rules and regulations shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter.
(Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.08 APPEALS.
   Appeals from any ruling of any official hereunder shall be made to Council
within ten days after such ruling has been made, and Council shall have
authority to annul, modify or affirm any such ruling appealed from, in
conformity with the intent and purpose of this chapter. (Ord. 1975- 42. Passed
5-20-75.)
191.09 INFORMATION CONFIDENTIAL.
   All returns and information relating to the business of any person required
to collect the tax imposed by this chapter and coming into the possession of
the Director of Finance, or any official or employee of the Municipality, shall
be held confidential. No disclosures thereof shall be made unless ordered by a
court of competent jurisdiction excepting, however, that the Director may
furnish the Bureau of Internal Revenue, Treasury Department, of the United
States, or the Department of Taxation of the State of Ohio, with copies of
returns filed.
(Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.10 INTEREST ON UNPAID TAX.
   In addition to interest as provided in Section
191.04, a penalty of ten percent per
year or fraction thereof shall be imposed on any tax not paid when due.
(Ord. 1975-42. Passed 5-20-75.)
191.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever, being a person charged by the provisions of this chapter
with the duty of collecting or paying the taxes imposed by this chapter,
willfully fails or refuses to charge and collect or to pay such taxes, or to
make return to the Director of Finance as required by this chapter, or to
permit the Director or his duly authorized agent to examine his books and other
records, in or upon any premises where the same are kept to the extent
necessary to verify any return made or to ascertain and assess the tax imposed
by this chapter if no return was made, or to maintain and keep his books and
other records for three years or such lesser or greater time as may be
permitted or required by the Director is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a
first offense and for a second or other subsequent offense is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
   (b)    Whoever violates Section
191.09 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree for each such violation
and shall thereafter be disqualified from acting in any official capacity
whatsoever in connection with the assessment or collection of taxes under this
chapter.
