CHAPTER 705
Billiard Rooms
705.01   Definitions.
705.02   Permit required; exceptions
705.03   Application for permit.
705.04   Citizenship required.
705.05   Contents of application.
705.06   Investigation of applicants; issuance of permit; appeal; fee.
705.07   Expiration of permit.
705.08   Transfer of permit.
705.09   Hours of operation.
705.10   Permitting minors to play pool or billiard.
705.11   Cleanliness.
705.12   Posting of permit.
705.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate billiard and pool tables - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
 
 
 
705.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Billiards” means any of the several games played with balls which are
impelled by a cue on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge or cushions, and
shall include all forms of the game known as pool.
   (b)   “Billiard room” means any public place wherein the game of billiards
is permitted to be played.
      (Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.02 PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   No person shall openly conduct, maintain or operate a billiard room within
the Municipality without first having obtained a permit therefor. However, the
provisions of this chapter shall not apply to private residences or schools.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.03 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   Every person desiring to open or maintain a billiard room must make
application to the Mayor for a permit therefor, which application shall be in
the form prescribed in this chapter. Such application shall be filed at least
ten days prior to the time of granting such permit.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.04 CITIZENSHIP REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be granted to a person who is not a citizen of the United
States.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.05 CONTENTS OF APPLICATION.
   Every applicant for a permit shall file with the Mayor a written application
stating the full name and address, including the street and number, of the
applicant, or if more than one person or if an association or firm, the full
names of all parties interested and the addresses, including street and number.
If the applicant is a club, society or corporation, the application shall
contain a complete list of the officers thereof, with their names and
addresses, and shall also give the names of one or more persons whom such
applicant desired to designated as the person or persons in charge, with their
addresses. The application shall also state:
   (a)   The premises where the billiard room is to be conducted;
   (b)   The age of the applicants in the case of individuals, and the age of
the manager and officers, in the case of a club, society or corporation;
   (c)   Whether the applicant or manager is a citizen of the United States;
   (d)   Whether the applicant has ever been engaged in operating a billiard
room, and when, where and how long in each place within the past five years;
   (e)   The names of the owner of the premises in which the billiard room is
located and the complete address of such owner.
   The application shall be signed by the applicant.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.06 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; APPEAL; FEE.
   The Mayor shall cause an investigation to be made as to the character of the
applicant and of the person who is to have the general management of the
business. The application shall be rejected if the Mayor finds any of the
persons named in the application not of good moral character, or that any of
the persons have previously been connected with any billiard room where the
license has been revoked, or where any of the provisions with reference to
billiard rooms have been violated, or if the billiard room sought to be
licensed does not comply in every way with the regulations, ordinances and laws
applicable thereto.
   If the application is rejected, the applicant shall be notified in writing
of the reasons therefor, and shall then have the right to appeal to Council,
which, after full hearing, shall either confirm the rejection or order the
permit issued. Such appeal shall be taken within ten days after notice of
rejection of the application and shall be heard at the next ensuing regular
meeting of Council.
   Every party to whom a permit is granted shall pay an annual fee of four
hundred dollars ($400.00) for the first table, and sixty dollars ($60.00) for
each additional table, provided that when the applicant is a society or club
not organized for profit, no fee shall be charged for the use of any table or
tables.
(Ord. 1960-37. Passed 3-8-60; Ord. 2001-27. Passed 5-1-01.)
705.07 EXPIRATION OF PERMIT.
   All permits granted under the provisions of this chapter shall expire one
year after the date of issue.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.08 TRANSFER OF PERMIT.
   No transfer of a permit either as to person or place shall be permitted
without the consent of the Mayor, which consent shall be endorsed upon the
permit.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.09 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person shall operate a billiard room between the hours of 12:00 midnight
and 5:00 a.m. or harbor or permit any person to be or remain in any such room
between these hours, other than regular employees.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.10 PERMITTING MINORS TO PLAY POOL OR BILLIARDS.
   No owner or keeper of a billiard room, or owner or keeper of a billiard
table at any other public place, shall permit a minor under the age of eighteen
years to play billiards or pool, or be and remain in such room or public place.
However, a minor under eighteen years of age, when accompanied by either parent
or his legal guardian, may be permitted to play both billiards and pool, or be
and remain in such room or public place. And provided further that an adult
person who is in charge of a group of minor children under the age of eighteen
years may bring such group into a billiard or pool room for the purpose of
permitting them to play both billiards and pool and such group may be permitted
to play both billiards and pool or be in and remain in such a room or public
place so long as they remain under the supervision and control of such adult
person.
   For the fine and costs in a prosecution under this section, the billiard
table and fixtures at the place where the violation occurred are liable on
execution without exemption.
705.11 CLEANLINESS.
   All billiard rooms shall be kept at all times in a clean, healthful and
sanitary condition. (Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.12 POSTING OF PERMIT.
   Every permittee shall keep his permit conspicuously posted in his billiard
room. Any permit may be revoked by the Mayor for disorderly or immoral conduct
on the premises, or for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
705.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 1931-5. Passed 2-26-31.)
                                                                                                    
CHAPTER 709
Fortunetelling and Clairvoyancy
709.01    License required.
709.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Petty theft by deception - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
 
 
709.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, not legally licensed to do so, shall represent himself to be an
astrologer, fortuneteller, clairvoyant or palmist.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
709.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day's continued violation shall be deemed a separate offense.
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 717
Mechanical Game Devices
717.01   Definitions.
717.02   Exhibitor’s license required; transferability.
717.03   Device license required.
717.04   Fees; issuance of license and registration.
717.05   Affidavit of ownership required.
717.06   Application for license and registration; denial.
717.07   Records to be kept by Mayor.
717.08   Rules and regulations; affidavit of character.
717.09   Minors prohibited.
717.10   Proximity to schools and churches.
717.11   Seizure and destruction.
717.12   Revocation or suspension of license.
717.13   Appeals.
717.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Mechanical musical instruments - see BUS. REG. Ch.
721
Gamerooms as permitted use - see P. & Z.
1147.01
 
 
 
717.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless otherwise provided:
   (a)   “Exhibitor” means any person owning and exhibiting or contracting or
permitting any mechanical game device, as herein defined, to be installed, used
and exhibited in his own place of business irrespective of the ownership of
such devices.
   (b)   “Mechanical game device” or “electrically operated game device” means
a machine which, upon the insertion of a coin or slug, operates, or may be
operated, for use as a game, contest or amusement of any description, or which
may be used for any such game, contest or amusement, and which contains no
automatic pay-off device for the return of slugs, money, coins, checks, tokens,
merchandise or anything of value, or which contains no automatic device by the
operation of which the player may win at uncertain intervals a free game, a
free play or any other additional amusement. This definition shall not include
any mechanical or electrically operated game device which is a gambling device
per se. This definition is not intended to and does not include merchandise
vending machines.
(c)   “Owner” means any person having title to any such mechanical game device
as herein defined. (Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.02 EXHIBITOR’S LICENSE REQUIRED; TRANSFERABILITY.
   No exhibitor shall install or permit the use of any mechanical game device
without first obtaining an exhibitor’s license and registration therefor from
the Mayor. The Mayor shall not issue a license or registration to any exhibitor
who installs or proposes to install any gambling device per se. The Mayor shall
not issue a license or registration for any device that is adapted to or may be
readily converted into a gambling device. Such license and registration shall
be issued only to persons of good moral character and shall not be transferable
to any other person.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.03 DEVICE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   Each individual mechanical game device shall be licensed and
registered. No person shall keep, maintain, permit or allow any unlicensed and
unregistered device to be in or upon any public place or place of business
under the control, supervision or direction of such person except as in this
chapter may be exempted from license and registration.
   (b)   Any public place or place of business that permits more than two
mechanical or electrical game amusement devices shall be required to obtain a
special use permit as provided in Section
1147.01 of the Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 1981-104. Passed 12-15-81.)
717.04 FEES; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE AND REGISTRATION.
   The Mayor is authorized to issue licenses and registrations to exhibitors of
mechanical game devices upon fulfillment of the requirements set forth in this
chapter and upon the payment of the following fees:
   (a)   For one-dollar ($1.00) to five-dollar ($5.00) mechanical game devices,
the fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00) each per year.
   (b)   For five dollars ($5.00), ten dollars ($10.00) or higher denomination
mechanical game devices, the fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) each
per year.
   However, no license or registration shall be issued to an applicant until
the Mayor shall have found that such applicant is of good moral character, the
lack of which on the applicant shall be deemed grounds for denial or revocation
of such license and registration by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57; Ord. 2001-27. Passed 5-1-01.)
717.05 AFFIDAVIT OF OWNERSHIP REQUIRED.
   The exhibitor shall be required to take out a machine license and
registration for each mechanical game device used, and shall be required to
furnish the Mayor with the name of the owner of such mechanical game device. In
the event the exhibitor is also the owner of such device, he shall file an
affidavit with the Mayor setting forth that he is the actual bona fide owner of
such mechanical game device and that, as such owner, he receives all the
benefits from the operation thereof and that no other person has any actual or
beneficial interest therein, either directly or indirectly.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.06 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE AND REGISTRATION; DENIAL.
   Every applicant for an exhibitor’s license and registration shall file an
affidavit with the Mayor prior to receiving such license and registration
stating the number of machines intended to be exhibited, together with an
affidavit as to good moral character, as required by Section
717.04. Upon payment of the fees required by this chapter, the Mayor shall
issue a license and registration which shall contain the name and address of
the licensee, the number of mechanical game devices exhibited, the address at
which it is desired to exhibit and operate the devices, the nature of the
business conducted at such place, the make, name and model and other
identifying information with reference to the particular devices desired to be
exhibited, the serial number of the license and such other information as the
Mayor, in his discretion, may require. Such license and registration shall be
displayed by the exhibitor in a conspicuous place within his place of business
and in close proximity to the mechanical game devices licensed and registered
therein. A licensee desiring to exhibit additional mechanical game devices
shall apply for a license and registration to cover the exhibition of such
additional mechanical game devices in the manner above set forth, and shall pay
the fees required by this chapter for the exhibition of any such additional
mechanical game devices.
   All licenses for one year shall expire on the anniversary date of issuance
in the following year, unless earlier revoked by the Mayor.
   No license fee shall be charged for mechanical devices exhibited and
operated solely for the benefit of a charitable, benevolent, religious or
eleemosynary institution.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to deny, for reasonable cause,
applications for licenses.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.07  RECORDS TO BE KEPT BY MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall keep and maintain on file in his office a full and complete
list of all licenses issued under this chapter, and also a full and complete
list of all mechanical game devices which are licensed and registered under
this chapter, together with a cross index showing the location of each such
licensed and registered mechanical game device.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS; AFFIDAVIT OF CHARACTER.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to establish, adopt and
enforce, or cause to be enforced, such rules and regulations governing the
issuance of the licenses and registrations required under this chapter as he
may deem reasonable and necessary and not inconsistent with this chapter.
   Applicants for licenses under this chapter, as required in Section
717.02, shall be of good moral character, and the Mayor shall adopt and enforce
a rule or regulation requiring an affidavit by each applicant relative to any
arrest or conviction of the applicant for any crime involving morals or moral
turpitude within a period of five years immediately preceding the date of
application.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.09 MINORS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall permit any mechanical game device to be played by any minor
under the age of seventeen years, unless such minor is accompanied by a parent,
guardian or other adult relative. (Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.10 PROXIMITY TO SCHOOLS AND CHURCHES.
   No mechanical game device shall be operated within a distance of 500 feet of
any school or building used for religious purposes.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.11 SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION.
   Any machine, apparatus, contrivance or device which is adapted to or may be
readily converted into a gambling device, which has been exhibited or made use
of by any owner or exhibitor in violation of this chapter may be seized and
destroyed in accordance with the provisions of Section
517.11.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.12 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the
rules and regulations established and adopted by the Mayor as herein provided,
except those relating to the exhibition or operation of such machine or device
for gambling, shall, for the first violation thereof, have his license
suspended by the Mayor for not less than ten nor more than thirty days; for the
second violation thereof, such license shall be suspended by the Mayor for not
less than thirty nor more than sixty days; and for the third violation thereof,
such license shall be revoked by the Mayor. For violation of any provision of
this chapter or the rules and regulations established and adopted by the Mayor
as herein provided relating to the exhibition or operation of such machine or
device for gambling, such license shall be revoked by the Mayor.
   In case of any hearing before the Mayor involving the denial of a license to
an applicant therefor, as provided by Section
717.06, or involving the suspension or revocation of a license, as provided
herein, the Mayor shall notify such applicant or licensee of such hearing by
registered mail directed to the last address of such applicant or licensee on
file with the Mayor. In the event such license is denied, suspended or revoked,
the Mayor shall notify such applicant or licensee of such denial, suspension or
revocation in the same manner as provided above for notification of hearings.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.13 APPEALS.
   There is hereby created the Game Device Board of Appeals consisting of the
Director of Public Safety, who shall be Chairman, the Director of Finance, who
shall be Secretary, and the Director of Law. An applicant who has been refused
a license or a licensee whose license has been suspended or revoked, as
provided in Section
717.12, may appeal to such Board, within ten days after the date of mailing by
the Mayor of notice of denial, suspension or revocation, by filing written
notice of such appeal with the Chairman of the Board. The Board shall consider
such appeal within five days after the date upon which written appeal is filed
with the Board. The Board may, in its discretion, consider such appeal, either
solely upon the evidence considered by the Mayor in cases of denial, suspension
or revocation of license respectively, or may consider such appeal de novo.
Upon such hearing the Board shall affirm, disaffirm or modify such order of
denial, suspension or revocation from which an appeal has been perfected, and
the denial of the Board shall be final. The Board shall also hear appeals
concerning licenses of mechanical musical instruments.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
717.99 PENALTY.
   Any exhibitor who shall exhibit or permit the exhibition of any mechanical
game device without first having obtained a license and registration therefor
and paying the fees herein required, or any person who shall exhibit or permit
to be exhibited any mechanical game device for which a license and registration
has not been first obtained, or any person who shall exhibit or operate such
machine or device or who shall permit the same to be exhibited or operated for
gambling, or any person who shall violate this chapter or any rule or
regulation of the Mayor established and adopted hereunder is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 721
Mechanical Musical Instruments
721.01    Definition.
721.02    License required.
721.03    Application for license.
721.04    Fees; issuance of license and registration.
721.05    Records to be kept by the Mayor.
721.06    Obscene recordings; peace disturbances.
721.07    Mayor to make regulations.
721.08    Revocation of license.
721.09    Appeal from denial or revocation order.
721.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Fraudulent use of false coin or slug - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Disturbing the peace - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
509
Mechanical amusement devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
717
Game Device Board of Appeals - see BUS. REG.
717.13
Public dances and dance halls - see BUS. REG. Ch.
733
 
 
 
721.01 DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, “mechanical musical instrument” means and includes
any amusement machine, apparatus or device designed or constructed for the
purpose of producing, reproducing or playing any musical or vocal tone or tones
or combination of tones, the operation or use of which instrument is permitted,
controlled, allowed or made possible by the deposit or placing of any coin,
plate, disc, token or key into any slot, crevice or other opening in such
instrument.
   "Premises which are open to the public" or similar words as used in this
chapter shall not include private clubs, headquarters and meeting places of
fraternal and other societies, associations and bodies unless such premises are
leased or rented for public purposes.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain, operate or permit to be maintained or operated,
in, upon or about any premises under his control which are open to the public,
any mechanical musical instrument unless a license and registration therefor
shall have been first obtained from the Mayor.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for the license shall be made to the Mayor upon such blank forms
as shall be prescribed therefor. On such application, the applicant shall state
his name, whether an individual, partnership or corporation, if a partnership
the names and addresses of the partners composing the same, the addresses at
which it is desired to maintain and operate the mechanical musical instrument,
the nature of the business conducted at such place, the make, name, model,
serial number and other identifying information with reference to the
particular mechanical musical instruments which it is desired to operate, the
name and address of the owner of such instruments, and such other and further
information as the Mayor, in his discretion, may require.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.04 FEES; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE AND REGISTRATION.
   Upon the filing of the aforesaid application and the payment of the sum of
fifteen dollars ($15.00), which is the annual license fee for the license
hereinafter mentioned, the Mayor shall issue to the applicant a license which
shall entitle the licensee to maintain and operate, at the premises mentioned
in the application, the mechanical musical instruments described in the
application, subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter and other
ordinances of the Municipality and also subject to the rules and regulations
which may be promulgated under this chapter. At the time of issuing the
license, the Mayor shall also issue to the licensee a registration slip or
sticker for each mechanical musical instrument described in the application.
The license fee hereinabove mentioned shall be the annual license fee for the
fiscal year which shall expire December 31 of each calendar year.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57. )
721.05 RECORDS TO BE KEPT BY THE MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall keep and maintain on file in his office a full and complete
list of all licensees licensed under this chapter, and also a full and complete
list of all mechanical musical instruments which are registered under this
chapter, together with a cross index showing the location of each registered
mechanical musical instrument.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.06 OBSCENE RECORDINGS; PEACE DISTURBANCES.
   No person shall play, produce or reproduce upon any mechanical musical
instrument any obscene selection or rendition. No person shall use or permit to
be used or maintained any mechanical musical instrument in such manner as to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. (Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-
57.)
721.07 MAYOR TO MAKE REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to establish, adopt and
enforce, or cause to be enforced, such rules and regulations governing the
issuance of the licenses required under this chapter as he may deem reasonable
and necessary and not inconsistent with this chapter.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.08 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The license of any person violating any of the terms of this chapter or any
of the rules and regulations established and adopted by the Mayor, as herein
provided, shall be revoked by the Mayor. The Mayor is hereby authorized and
empowered to deny, for reasonable cause, applications for license.
   The Mayor shall notify any licensee of any hearing of the Mayor involving
the denial or revocation of such license. Such notification shall be by
registered mail directed to the last address of the licensee on file with the
Mayor.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.09 APPEAL FROM DENIAL OR REVOCATION ORDER.
   A licensee who has been refused a license or whose license has been revoked
may appeal in writing to the Game Device Board of Appeals within ten days after
the date of mailing of the notice of denial or revocation. The Board may
consider such appeal in whatever manner it may determine and its decision
thereon shall be final. Such written appeal shall be filed with the Chairman of
the Board.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
721.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall maintain or operate any mechanical musical instrument
in any public place without first having obtained a license and registration
therefor is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. Any licensee who
violates any other provision of this chapter or any rule of the Mayor
established and adopted hereunder shall be punished by having his license
revoked and, in addition thereto, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
                                                                                                   
CHAPTER 725
Motels and Inns
725.01    Registration by false name.
725.02    Failure of employee to give information.
725.99    Penalty.

Defrauding a livery or hostelry - see GEN. OFF.

725.01 REGISTRATION BY FALSE NAME.
   No person shall register for accommodations at any motel, hotel or inn under
a false, fictitious or assumed name without first making his true name known to
the person in charge thereof by presenting a valid form of photo identification
such as a state issued driver's license or identification card, or United
States passport.
(Ord. 2014-120. Passed 11-18-14.)
725.02 FAILURE OF EMPLOYEE TO GIVE INFORMATION.
   No person employed or connected with the management of a motel, hotel or
inn, having knowledge of a false, fictitious or assumed name being registered
at the hotel, shall fail, refuse or neglect to furnish information in relation
thereto to any court when called upon to do so. (ORC 3731.18; Ord. 1957-33.
Passed 3-19-57.)
725.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
                                                                                                
CHAPTER 727
Parking Lots
727.01    Person defined; permit required; fee; maintenance.
727.02    False statement by affidavit.
727.03    Closing lot for violations.
727.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Private garages in residence districts - see P. & Z.
1143.04
Off-street parking - see P. & Z. Ch.
1181
 
 
 
 
727.01 PERSON DEFINED; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; MAINTENANCE.
   (a)    "Person" as defined in this chapter includes any firm, partnership,
association, corporation, organization, lessor or lessee.
   (b)    Any person desiring to park automobiles or motor vehicles within any
area within the City and who charge a fee for such parking of automobiles or
who use their parking area as an auxiliary, additional or overflow lot to a
parking lot for which a fee is charged shall apply for a permit. Such person
shall upon making such application to Council, submit a drawing and/or
affidavit stating the number of spaces available and to be used for parking
automobiles. Upon the determination of Council that the permit should be
granted, the applicant shall pay to the Director of Finance as a further
condition for the permit and/or operation of the parking lot, a fee of two
dollars ($2.00) for each and every parking space available. Such available
space to be determined by the affidavit of the applicant, subject to
verification and approval by the City.
   (c)    All permits shall be issued by the Director of Finance, subject to
the above, and only after approval by Council.
   All permits issued hereunder shall expire one year following the date of
issuance.
   (d)   All parking lots within the City shall be maintained free of dust,
weeds, papers, trash, snow, ice and other undesirable materials. All snow and
ice shall be removed within a reasonable time, which will ordinarily not exceed
twelve hours after the abatement of any storm during which such snow and ice
may have accumulated. No person removing snow and ice from any parking lot
within the City shall deposit same on the pavement or sidewalk of any public
street or on any tree lawn in any public street, except the tree lawn
immediately in front of the parking lot from which the snow and ice are
removed.
   (e)   Signs may be erected and maintained during the period authorized under
the permit, such signs not to exceed eight square feet in surface area.
(Ord. 2023-051. Passed 4-18-23.)
727.02 FALSE STATEMENT BY AFFIDAVIT.
   Any person owning and/or operating a parking area within the City who makes
false statements by affidavit concerning the parking area available and/or the
number of parking spaces available shall forthwith, upon notification by the
Mayor, cease using such area for parking facilities.
(Ord. 1955-67. Passed 7-25-55.)
727.03 CLOSING LOT FOR VIOLATIONS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed, upon being notified of any
violation concerning the above permit or operation of a parking area, to
forthwith order such parking area closed for the remainder of the calendar year
during which the parking area is in operation. (Ord. 1955-67. Passed 7-25-55.)
727.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 729
   Peddlers, Itinerant Vendors and Solicitors
729.01   Purpose; license required.
729.02   Application for license; fee; duration; revocation.
729.03   Exemptions.
729.04   Restrictions; hours; conduct.
729.05   Itinerant vendors; license; fee.
729.06   Resident prohibition by notice.
729.07   Organizational liability.
729.08   Display of license.
729.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate peddlers, solicitors and itinerant vendors - see Ohio R.C.
715.61, 715.64
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
 
 
 
729.01 PURPOSE; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   The purpose of this chapter is to regulate peddlers, solicitors and
itinerant vendors in order to prevent fraud and crime and to protect the
privacy of residents within the Municipality.
   (b)   No person shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange, solicit
the purchase of, or gift of, any goods, wares, merchandise or other articles or
value, or solicit funds for any purpose or cause, or offer any services for
hire or commission from a vehicle or on foot, in any place in, upon, along or
through the street, avenues, alleys or other public places within the
Municipality, or in, at, or near any private property within the Municipality
unless such person is the holder of a license which is in full force and effect
and issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, which license such
person shall at all times have with such person while exercising such calling
and exhibit to any prospective purchaser, any person being solicited, police
officer or official of this Municipality upon demand.
(Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.02 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE; DURATION; REVOCATION.
   (a)   Any person desiring to sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange or
solicit the purchase of, or gift of any goods, wares, merchandise or other
articles of value, or solicit funds for any purpose or cause, or offer any
services for hire or commission from a vehicle or on foot within the
Municipality, shall make application for a license to the Chief of Police and
shall submit the completed application, along with the appropriate fee, to such
office, on a form supplied by the Chief of Police which shall contain the
following information:
      (1)   Full name of the applicant;
      (2)   Date of birth of the applicant;
      (3)   Local address, if any;
      (4)   Permanent home address verified by a state driver’s license, state
identification card and/or like form of identification;
      (5)   A physical description of the applicant, setting forth the age,
height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex;
      (6)   Social security number of the applicant;
      (7)   A description of the nature of the business and the goods, wares,
merchandise, property and/or services to be sold;
      (8)   An explanation of the cause or purpose for which funds are to be
solicited and an indication of whether funds solicited will be tax deductible
by the donor;
      (9)   Telephone number of the applicant;
      (10)   Name, address and description of the organization that the peddler
or solicitor represents;
      (11)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a crime and, if
so, where and the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty imposed
therefor, if any;
      (12)   Such other information as the Chief of Police may require in order
to protect the public health, safety and/or general welfare.
   (b)   All license applications shall be referred to the Chief of Police who
shall, within five (5) days after receipt of the completed application, issue a
license unless the Chief finds that:
      (1)   The applicant has provided false, misleading or deceptive
information in his or her application; and/or
      (2)   The applicant or any solicitor or peddler named on the license
application has been convicted of a felony violation or misdemeanor violation
involving weapons, theft, moral turpitude or violence within the past five (5)
years.
   (c)   All licenses under this chapter shall be valid for not more than one
hundred eighty (180) days. A separate license shall be required for each
individual solicitor or peddler even though there may be a single employer.
   (d)   Each applicant shall pay a nonrefundable license application fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00), which fee shall be paid at the time the
application is submitted.
   (e)   Once issued, a license may be used only in conformity with the laws of
the Municipality and the State of Ohio; may not be assigned or transferred;
must be carried by the licensee at all times; and may be revoked or suspended
by the Chief of Police for any of the following causes:
      (1)   The licensee or person preparing the application on behalf of the
licensee provided false, misleading or deceptive information in the license
application;
      (2)   The licensee is convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving
fraud or moral turpitude; or
      (3)   The licensee violates any provision of this chapter or peddles or
solicits in an unlawful manner;
      (4)   Upon written complaint being filed with the Police Department, that
the licensee has made himself or herself obnoxious to the public by use of
indecent, profane or insulting language or has made or perpetuated any
misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation or sale,
and if said complaint is found to be true, the license of such solicitor or
peddler shall be revoked.
         (Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.03 EXEMPTIONS.
   The following persons are hereby declared exempt from the payment of any
license fee for the licenses hereinabove mentioned: any person selling the
products of his or her own raising; a manufacturer selling any article
manufactured by him or her; a person selling newspapers; a duly authorized
solicitor soliciting funds for any purpose or cause or soliciting the purchase
of goods, wares, merchandise or gifts for or on behalf of any recognized
educational, civic, religious or charitable organization and all other persons
otherwise exempted by law. However, no person shall engage in the operation of
selling or soliciting, as more fully described in Section
729.01(b), without first obtaining a license from the Chief of Police to do so,
which license shall be issued without a fee, shall be revocable as provided in
Section
729.02(e).
(Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.04 RESTRICTIONS; HOURS; CONDUCT.
   Every person to whom a license to peddle or solicit is issued shall be
governed by the following rules and regulations:
   (a)   No person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall peddle or
solicit except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. or one-half hour
after sunset whichever is later.
   (b)   No peddler or solicitor shall enter or attempt to enter a residence,
house, apartment, or other dwelling unit within the Municipality without an
express invitation from an adult occupant of the residence, house, apartment or
other dwelling.
   (c)   No peddler or solicitor shall engage in any peddling or solicitation
other than that specified in the license application.
   (d)   No peddler or solicitor shall by any device make unlawful noises, nor
shall any peddler or solicitor remain at the residence, house, apartment or
other dwelling in the Municipality without the consent of any adult occupant of
the residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in the Municipality.
      (Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.05 ITINERANT VENDORS; LICENSE; FEE.   
   No person, whether principal or agent, shall open or conduct a temporary
store or other place for selling of wearing apparel or any other goods, wares
or merchandise within the Municipality, or offer any such article for sale
until such has complied with the provisions of Section
729.02 and procured from the Chief of Police a license to open such store or
conduct such sale.
   Such license fee shall be paid to the Chief of Police in the sum of one
hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.06 RESIDENT PROHIBITION BY NOTICE.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no peddler or
solicitor, while peddling or soliciting, shall call upon, knock at the door or
ring the door bell of any residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in the
Municipality upon which there is posted at the entrance a notice which reads
“No Peddlers or Solicitors Allowed” or words of similar import, which clearly
prohibit peddlers or solicitors on the premises, unless such peddler or
solicitor has previously been invited upon the premises by the owner, lessee or
an adult occupant thereof.
(Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.07 ORGANIZATIONAL LIABILITY.
   The organization sponsoring or employing individuals violating any of the
provisions of this chapter may be prosecuted and held liable for the criminal
penalties contained herein.
(Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.08 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Any peddler or solicitor shall, at all times while soliciting or peddling,
display said license on the outside of their person in such a manner so as to
be clearly visible to residents. Upon request by any resident, police officer
or municipal official, a solicitor or peddler shall present said license for
further inspection.
(Ord. 2002-078. Passed 10-1-02.)
729.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. If the offender, or any representative of the offender’s business
has previously been convicted of a violation of this chapter, then the
violation is a misdemeanor of the first degree. Any offender may have his or
her license revoked by the Mayor or the Chief of Police. Each day’s continued
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-152. Passed 11-7-07.)
CHAPTER 730
Personal Property Sales, (Garage, Yard, Estate)
730.01   Purpose.
730.03   Permit required.
730.05   Permit application; duration; revocation.
730.07   Regulations.
730.99    Penalty.
730.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the sale of household goods,
equipment, utensils, appliances, furniture, personal clothing or effects or
other similar personal property on any parcel(s) of real property in the City
that is classified as residential or has been used for residential purposes in
any manner.
(Ord. 2021-154. Passed 10-5-21.)
730.03 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation or association of persons, being the owner,
occupant or person in control of or having management of any parcel of real
property located in the City and classified as residential or has been used for
residential purposes in any manner shall hold, conduct or permit to be held or
conducted upon such property a sale for household goods, equipment, utensils,
appliances, furniture, personal clothing or effects or other similar personal
property unless a permit has been granted and the sale is conducted in
accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 2021-154. Passed 10-5-21.)
730.05 PERMIT APPLICATION; DURATION; REVOCATION.
   (a)   Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons desiring to
sell household goods, equipment, utensils, appliances, furniture, personal
clothing or effects or other similar personal property on any parcel of real
property located in the City and classified as residential or has been used for
residential purposes in any manner shall make application for a permit to the
Building Commissioner on a form supplied by the Building Commissioner which
shall contain the following information:
      (1)   Property address where the sale is to take place and the property
owner’s full name, date of birth, address, email address, phone number.
      (2)   Applicant’s full name, date of birth, address, email address, phone
number.
      (3)   Full name, date of birth, address, email address and phone number
of the person in charge of the sale.
      (4)   Date(s) and hours of the sale.
   (b)   All permits issued under this chapter shall be valid for the approved
date(s) of the sale.
   (c)   All permits issued under this chapter may be revoked for any of the
following reasons:
      (1)   Any violation of this chapter.
      (2)   False, misleading or deceptive information provided in the permit
application.
         (Ord. 2021-154. Passed 10-5-21.)
730.07 REGULATIONS.
   Every person, firm, corporation or association of persons to whom a permit
is issued under this chapter shall comply with the following rules and
regulations:
   (a)   No more than two (2) sales may take place within one (1) calendar
year.
   (b)   One (1) temporary sign as defined in Chapter
1163 is permitted for the sale and must comply with the provisions of said
chapter.
   (c)   The permit issued under this chapter shall be displayed and readily
accessible to any member of the City’s Police Department or other person upon
request.
   (d)   The permit issued under this chapter shall not be assigned to a
person, firm, corporation or association of persons not listed on the valid
permit issued under this chapter.
   (e)   The sale shall take place between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.
and shall not last longer than two (2) consecutive days.
   (f)   Traffic laws of the City and any other instructions as they are given
by any member of the City’s Police Department for the public health, safety
and/or general welfare shall be followed.
   (g)   The items to be sold must be displayed on the private property listed
on the permit issued under this chapter.
      (Ord. 2021-154. Passed 10-5-21.)
730.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. If the offender, or any representative of the offender’s business
has previously been convicted of a violation of this chapter, then the
violation is a misdemeanor of the first degree. Any offender may have his or
her permit revoked by the Building Commissioner. Each day’s continued violation
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2021-154. Passed 10-5-21.)
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 733
Rental Halls
733.01    Compliance required; rental hall defined.
733.02   Permit required; fee.
733.03   Permit revocation; prohibited conduct in a rental hall; hours of
operation.
733.04   Appeal to Board of Zoning Appeals.
733.05   Police attendance at rental hall events; costs.
733.99 Penalty.
   
CROSS REFERENCES
Public school entertainments and lectures excluded from municipal regulation -
see Ohio R.C. 715.48
Power to regulate public ballrooms - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Liquor control - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
529 
Minor's curfew- see GEN. OFF.
537.19 
Permitted use - see P. & Z.
1147.01 
 
 
 
733.01 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; RENTAL HALL DEFINED.
   No person shall conduct or operate any rental hall within the Municipality
except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. The term “rental
hall”, as used in this chapter, means any hall, place, restaurant or night club
the primary use of which is for private events such as parties, talent shows,
concerts, or other gatherings or functions, and a fee is charged to rent the
space or a fee is charged to the attendees for admission or attendance. This
section does not apply to spaces that are regulated by the Ohio Department of
Liquor Control.
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
733.02 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   No event shall be held at any rental hall without first obtaining a
permit therefor.
   (b)   The application for the permit shall be furnished by the Chief of
Police and state the start time, end time and location of the event, the fee or
charge for admission or attendance, the person or persons who will be in charge
or control thereof while the same is being given, the person or persons
promoting it, a statement regarding the consumption of liquor at the event,
anticipated number of attendees and any other information the Chief of Police
deems necessary.
   (c)   Each application for a permit shall be submitted to the Chief of
Police, or his or her designee, no less than ten (10) calendar days in advance
of the event and the application must be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in
the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
733.03 PERMIT REVOCATION; PROHIBITED CONDUCT IN A RENTAL HALL; HOURS OF
OPERATION.
   (a)   Any permit may be revoked for providing false information on the
permit application, if any of the grounds upon which the permit was issued no
longer exists, or for any violation of this chapter. A prior history of
violations shall be cause for refusal to issue a permit. The rental hall may be
entered at any time by the Mayor or designee, his or her authorized
representative or any City police officer for the purpose of ensuring
compliance with this chapter.
   (b)   No person, when conducting an event in a rental hall, shall permit:
      (1)   Any person having in his possession or being under the influence
of, selling or offering for sale, or giving away or using any drugs in
violation of City ordinances or the Ohio Revised Code.
      (2)   Gambling in any form unless permitted by State law or the City’s
ordinances.
      (3)   Fighting or other disorderly conduct.
      (4)   The carrying of knives or other weapons on the premises, except the
lawful carrying of firearms as defined in Ohio R.C. 2923.11.
      (5)   The sale of any beer or intoxicating liquor unless properly
licensed by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control.
      (6)   The furnishing of any beer or intoxicating liquor to a minor in
violation of City ordinances or the Ohio Revised Code.
   (c)   No event at any rental hall shall take place between the hours of 1:00
a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
733.04 APPEAL TO BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   If the Mayor refuses to issue a license, the applicant may appeal from such
decision to the Board of Zoning Appeals. The action of the Board of Zoning
Appeals upon such application shall be final.
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
733.05 POLICE ATTENDANCE AT RENTAL HALL EVENTS; COSTS.
   A full-time or part-time member of a Police Department shall be present for
each event at a rental hall that is subject to this chapter where there are
forty (40) or more attendees or if alcohol is being served at the event,
beginning from the start time to the end time listed in the permit application
in order to protect the public peace and to insure order. The expense of such
police attendance at a rental hall shall be the responsibility of the
permittee.
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
733.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each offense. Each day’s violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
   (b)   Any permittee that violates any provision of this chapter is subject
to the following fines:
      (1)   Upon the first offense, a warning letter.
      (2)   Upon the second offense, a fine of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00).
      (3)   Upon the third offense, a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      (4)   Upon the forth and each subsequent offense, a fine of seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (c)   The imposition of any penalty or fine shall not preclude the Director
of Law from instituting an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of
competent jurisdiction to restrain, correct or abate a violation or to require
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.            
   (d)   Each day such violation occurs or continues shall constitute a
separate offense. If the fine(s) listed in subsection (b) hereof is not paid
within thirty (30) days of receiving notice of the fine(s), the City may take
such actions as it deems necessary to collect such fines.
(Ord. 2022-138. Passed 12-20-22.)
                                                                                                     
CHAPTER 737
Real Estate Business
737.01    Certain practices prohibited.       
737.02    Notice.
737.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Fair housing - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4112
 
 
 
737.01 CERTAIN PRACTICES PROHIBITED.
   No person who receives or expects to receive pecuniary gain from the sale of
real property shall:
   (a)    Incite, arouse or refer to neighborhood unrest, community tension or
racial, religious or nationality change in a neighborhood or on a particular
street, for the purpose of or in connection with soliciting or inducing a
listing of real property for sale or lease or inducing or promoting the sale or
lease of real property;
   (b)    Promote or influence, or attempt to promote or influence, a property
owner, occupant or tenant to list for sale, sell, remove from or lease real
property by referring to race, color, religion or national origin of neighbors,
tenants, prospective buyers or occupants of real property;
   (c)    Resort to or engage in any harassment, intimidation or threats in
attempting to induce a property owner or tenant to list for sale, sell, remove
from or lease real property. (Ord. 1964-54. Passed 5-12-64.)
737.02 NOTICE.
   All condominium and/or cooperative association officers and/or trustees must
notify the City in writing of their names, address, telephone number and
position held in such organization within thirty days of taking office.
(Ord. 1981-53. Passed 7-7-81.)
737.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for a first offense and a misdemeanor of the first degree for a
second or subsequent offense.
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 741
Sale of Firearms
741.01   Permit to dispose of concealable weapons.
741.02    Application for permit.
741.03    Permit revocation.
741.04    Daily report of sales.
741.05    Permit to purchase concealable weapons; application.
741.06    Responsibility of Chief of Police.
741.07    Pocket knives; identification and registration.
741.08    Gift or sale to minors.
741.09    Sale of ammunition; record required.
741.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Carrying concealed weapons - see GEN. OFF.
545.02
Unlawful transactions in weapons- see GEN. OFF.
549.06
Improperly furnishing firearms to minors - see GEN. OFF.
549.07
 
 
 
741.01 PERMIT TO DISPOSE OF CONCEALABLE WEAPONS.
   No person shall engage in the business of selling, or shall sell or give
away to any person, within the City, any pistol, revolver, derringer, bowie
knife, dirk or other weapon of similar character, which can be concealed on the
person, without securing a permit to do so as hereinafter provided. No person
having secured such permit shall sell or give away any such weapon to any
person within the City who has not secured a permit from the Chief of Police to
purchase such weapon in the manner hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   Any person desiring a permit authorizing the sale of any of the deadly
weapons mentioned in Section
741.01 shall make application in writing to the Chief of Police, setting out in
such application the full name and residence of the applicant, if an
individual, and, if a firm or corporation, the name and residence of each of
its members or officers. Such application shall also set out the location at
which it is intended or desired to conduct such business. Upon the receipt of
such application, it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to issue a permit
to the applicant.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.03 PERMIT REVOCATION.
   If the Chief of Police is satisfied that such applicant has violated any
provision of this chapter, then he shall revoke the permit to such person for
the selling of such weapons, and no other permit shall be issued to such person
for a period of three years thereafter.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.04 DAILY REPORT OF SALES.
   Every person who is permitted to deal in the deadly weapons described in
Section
741.01 shall make out and deliver to the Chief of Police, every day before the
hour of 12:00 noon, a legible and correct report of every sale or gift made
under authority of such permit during the preceding twenty-four hours. The
report shall contain the date of such sale or gift, the name of the purchaser
or donee, with his address and age, the number, kind, description and price of
such weapon, the number of the purchaser's permit and the reasons given by such
person for the purchase of such weapon, which report shall be substantially in
the following form:
      Permit number....................
      Weapon number....................
      Name of purchaser.................
      Address of purchaser..............
      Age of purchaser..................
      Kind or description of weapon ...................
      For what purpose purchased .....................
      Price .......................
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.05 PERMIT TO PURCHASE CONCEALABLE WEAPONS; APPLICATION.
   No person shall purchase any pistol, revolver, derringer, bowie knife, dirk
or other weapon of similar character, which can be concealed on the person,
without first securing from the Chief of Police a permit to do so. Before any
such permit is granted, an application in writing shall be made therefor,
setting forth the name, address, age, height, weight, complexion, nationality
and other elements of identification of the person desiring such permit. Such
application shall also contain a recommendation that the permit shall issue,
from two persons who shall be known to the Chief of Police, as persons of good
reputation and residents of the City for at least one year, or who shall appear
to be taxpayers residing within the City.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.06 RESPONSIBILITY OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to refuse such a permit to:
   (a)    All persons having been convicted of any crime;
   (b)    All vagabonds;
   (c)    All minors.
   Otherwise, it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to grant such permit.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.07 POCKET KNIVES; IDENTIFICATION AND REGISTRATION.
   Whoever gives or sells a pocket knife having a blade of two and one-half
inches in length or longer shall, before making such gift or sale, require the
purchaser to properly identify himself and require him to register in a book
kept for such purposes, giving his name, address and age. The register shall be
subject to inspection by any officer of the law upon demand.
   It shall be the duty of every person dealing in the sale of knives to post a
copy of this chapter in a conspicuous place in such place of business where
knives, knucklers or billies are exhibited or offered for sale.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.08 GIFT OR SALE TO MINORS.
   (a)    No person shall give, sell or exhibit for sale to a minor a knife
having a blade two and one-half inches in length or longer, or knucklers or a
billy.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
   (b)    (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
741.08(b), which was a re-enactment of Ohio R.C. 2903.06, was repealed by 1972
H 511, effective January 1, 1974.)
741.09 SALE OF AMMUNITION; RECORD REQUIRED.
   No person shall sell, give, barter or otherwise dispose of any ammunition
which is capable of use in any pistol, revolver or other weapon of similar
character which can be concealed on the person, unless every such transaction
is entered into a book by the person making such sale, gift, exchange or other
disposition, together with the address of the recipient, the date and the
description of the ammunition sufficient to identify it. Such entry shall be
signed by the recipient and witnessed by the person required to make such
record. A report shall be made to the Chief of Police within thirty days of
each such transaction on such forms as he may prescribe.
   Satisfactory proof of identity shall be required of the recipient by the
person making such sale, gift, exchange or other disposition of ammunition. The
means or method of such identification shall be recorded in the book required
to be kept hereunder.
(Ord. 1960-66. Passed 4-26-60.)
741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. Every purchase, sale or gift of any weapon shall be deemed a
separate offense.

CHAPTER 749
Topsoil Removal
749.01    Permit from Building Commissioner; fee.
749.02    Twenty feet limit from street.
749.03    Permit not granted when nuisance created.
749.04    Adequate drainage required.   
749.05    Four inches topsoil to be left above subsoil.
749.06    Replanting.
749.99    Penalty.
         
CROSS REFERENCES
Building permits and foundation requirements - see PART THIRTEEN- BUILDING CODE
Landscaping- see BLDG. Ch.
1357
 
 
 
749.01 PERMIT FROM BUILDING COMMISSIONER; FEE.
   The removal of topsoil or loam for commercial purposes or otherwise from any
land within the Municipality, except so far as necessary for the erection,
construction or alteration of buildings or the installation of sidewalks or
driveways, is hereby prohibited unless the owner of the property from which
such topsoil or loam is to be removed first obtains a written permit from the
Building Commissioner authorizing such removal.
   A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each acre to be stripped shall be charged
for such permit. The minimum fee is ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 1958-76. Passed 5-27-58.)
749.02 TWENTY FEET LIMIT FROM STREET.
   In order to preserve the public health, safety and welfare, no permit shall
be issued for the removal of topsoil within twenty feet of any dedicated street
in the Municipality, or within twenty feet of any existing dwelling, except in
connection with necessary work upon the premises.
(Ord. 1950-59. Passed 9-6-50.)
749.03 PERMIT NOT GRANTED WHEN NUISANCE CREATED.
   No permit shall be issued for the removal of topsoil where, because of the
development of surrounding properties, a nuisance would be created by such
removal because of dust or other unsafe or unhealthy conditions.
(Ord. 1950-59. Passed 9-6-50.)
749.04 ADEQUATE DRAINAGE REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be issued for the removal of topsoil unless the Building
Commissioner is satisfied that adequate drainage shall continue to exist on the
land from which topsoil is removed so that stagnant water or other conditions
dangerous to health and safety shall not be created. (Ord. 1950-59. Passed 9-6-
50.)
749.05 FOUR INCHES TOPSOIL TO BE LEFT ABOVE SUBSOIL.
   No topsoil shall be removed from any lands within the Municipality to such
an extent that less than four inches of topsoil remains above the subsoil, clay
or other unproductive ground, and any issuance of a permit in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter shall be conditioned by this limitation.
(Ord. 1950-59. Passed 9-6-50.)
749.06 REPLANTING.
   Any portion of land from which topsoil has been removed within the
provisions of this chapter shall be reseeded or replanted with grass or other
satisfactory planting within six months from such removal, in order to prevent
erosion, creation of dust or other conditions of nuisance. (Ord. 1950-59.
Passed 9-6-50.)
749.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each offense. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
                                                                                                
CHAPTER 751
Tow Trucks
751.01   Definition.
751.02    Identification.
751.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Emergency vehicle defined - see TRAF.
301.11
Truck defined - see TRAF.
301.49
Impounding vehicles; towing charges - see TRAF.
303.10
 
 
 
751.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this chapter, "tow truck" means any automobile, truck or
other vehicle adapted or used for the purpose of towing or otherwise removing
disabled motor vehicles.
(Ord. 1972-121. Passed 8-1-72.)
751.02 IDENTIFICATION.
   Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of offering towing
service or towing shall have imprinted on both sides of any vehicle used as a
tow truck, the name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or
corporation owning the vehicle. The name shall be at least three inches high
and not less than 3/8 inches wide while the address, place and phone number
shall be at least two inches high and not less than 3/8 inches wide.
Lettering shall be done in a color which will contrast sharply with the
background upon which it is painted and shall be placed in such position as to
be easily seen by anyone wishing to identify the vehicle. Markings must be kept
clear and distinct at all times and must be effaced or removed when the vehicle
is no longer used for this purpose.
(Ord. 1972-121. Passed 8-1-72.)
751.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
                                                                                                  
CHAPTER 753
Vehicles for Hire
753.01    License required.
753.02    License application.
753.03    Examination of vehicle.
753.04    Liability insurance.
753.05    License fee.
753.06    Issuance of license.
753.07    Waiver of requirements.
753.99    Penalty.
   
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
Bus defined - see TRAF.
301.05
Operator or chauffeur license requirements - see TRAF. Ch.
335
Bus stops and taxicab stands - see TRAF.
351.16
 
 
 
753.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate any automobile or other motor vehicle upon the
streets within the Municipality for the purpose of carrying passengers for hire
without first obtaining a license therefor, as herein provided.
(Ord. 1931-42. Passed 7-20-31.)
753.02 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for such license shall be made to the Mayor in writing and shall
contain the full name and address of the owner, the class of vehicle for which
the license is desired, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the
number of persons it is capable of carrying, the motor power thereof, a
statement on the route or routes upon or over which it is proposed to operate
and the schedule of trips to be made in the course of such operation.
(Ord. 1931-42. Passed 7-20-31.)
753.03 EXAMINATION OF VEHICLE .
   No license shall be issued for any vehicle until such vehicle has been
throughly and carefully inspected and examined and found to be in thoroughly
safe condition for the transportation of passengers, clean, fit, of good
appearance and well painted and varnished. Such examination shall be made by
the Mayor, or by some person designated by him, and similar examinations shall
be made at intervals of not more than ninety days after the issuance of a
license. The license issued for the operation of any given vehicle shall be
revoked if upon such re- examination it is at any time found not to be in the
condition required prior to the issuance of the license.
(Ord. 1931-42. Passed 7-20-31.)
753.04 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   No license shall be issued hereunder until and unless the applicant for a
license deposits with the Director of Finance a policy or certificate of
liability insurance for each vehicle for which a license is sought, accepted
and approved by the Mayor, in the sum of at least twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000) for injury to one person, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) for injury
to more than one person and five thousand dollars ($5,000) property damage in
any one accident through the operation of such vehicle. Such policy shall
further contain a clause obligating the surety company to give not less than
ten days' written notice before cancellation of the policy to the Mayor, and
such license shall expire upon the lapse or termination of such policy of
insurance.
(Ord. 1957-33. Passed 3-19-57.)
753.05 LICENSE FEE.
   Licenses shall be issued for the current year, or the remainder thereof,
from and after the issuance of the license. Once having been issued for any
given vehicle, a license shall be renewable as a matter of course for the next
ensuing calendar year upon the payment of the license fee, subject to the terms
and conditions of this section. Fees for the issuance of such license shall be
as follows:
   (a)    For the first vehicle licensed by any applicant, one hundred dollars
($100.00) when such license is issued for any portion of a year equal to six
months or more and eighty dollars ($80.00) when such license is issued for any
portion of a year which is less than six months.
   (b)    For each vehicle subsequently licensed for operation by an applicant
already holding a license issued under subsection (a) hereof, the sum of ten
dollars ($10.00).
   Such fee shall be payable at the time of making application for any license
hereunder or for the renewal of any such license. If the application is
refused, the cost and expense of the preliminary examination herein provided
for shall be deducted therefrom and the balance remaining shall be returned to
the applicant. (Ord. 1946-36. Passed 5-22-46.)
753.06 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   If the application for a license is found by the Mayor to conform to the
requirements of this chapter and the condition of the vehicle is as herein
required, the Mayor shall report the application to Council. If Council deems
it advisable that such license shall be issued, it shall pass a resolution
authorizing the issuance thereof under such terms and conditions as it may deem
proper. However, in the event of conflict between the resolution granting the
authority and this chapter, the resolution granting the authority shall in that
respect control.
   Council may, but need not, provide for notice to existing licensees of any
hearing on any application for authority for the operation of any public
vehicle.
(Ord. 1958-71. Passed 5-27-58.)
753.07 WAIVER OF REQUIREMENTS.
   Council may waive any requirement of this chapter relative to the manner or
form of any application for authority to operate any public vehicle, the fee in
connection with the application or the number of such vehicles applied for. The
passage of any resolution by Council authorizing the issuance of any license
for the operation of any public vehicle shall conclusively constitute a waiver
of all such requirements with respect to such grant of authority.
(Ord. 1958-71. Passed 5-27-58.)
753.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1931-42. Passed 7-20-31.)
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 755
Self-Service Filling Stations
755.01    Self-service gasoline sales.
755.02    Definitions.
755.03    Authorized attendant.
755.04    Installations.
755.05    Toilet facilities.
755.06    Air pumps.
755.07    Time limitations.
755.08    Safety devices.
755.09    Age limitation.
755.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Self-service filling stations - see Ohio R.C. 3741.14
 
 
 
755.01 SELF-SERVICE GASOLINE SALES.
   No person owning, leasing or operating a filling station shall permit any
person other than himself or an employee to dispense flammable and combustible
liquids used as motor fuels in a filling station except pursuant to the
regulations hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Approved self-service dispensing device" means a self-closing
dispensing nozzle without any latch open device, listed by Underwriter's
Laboratories.
   (b)    "Authorized attendant" means the owner, employee or agent, who is
authorized by the licensee to dispense gasoline and other motor fuels.
   (c)    "Full service" means that portion of the property where flammable and
combustible liquids used as motor fuel are stored and dispensed in fuel tanks
of motor vehicles by authorized service station attendants.
   (d)    "Island" means the raised portion of the driveway upon which the
dispensing equipment is located.
   (e)    "Self-service" means that portion of property where flammable and
combustible liquids used as motor fuel are stored and subsequently dispensed
from fixed approved fuel dispensing equipment into fuel tanks of motor vehicles
by persons other than the authorized service station attendants.
   (f)    "Split-island" means the sale of flammable and combustible liquids
used as motor fuel in service stations which shall be equipped with at least
one complete set of approved equipment for dispensing motor fuels at both self-
service and full service islands.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.03 AUTHORIZED ATTENDANT.
   A gasoline station owner, employee or agent shall not permit any person who
is not an authorized attendant to dispense flammable and combustible liquids
used as motor fuels in a service station unless:
   (a)    The service station is a split-island operation offering both full
and self-service dispensing equipment for each grade of motor fuel offered for
sale.
   (b)    A sign is posted over each island indicating in letters not less than
3 inches in height or less than one and one half inches in width indicating the
type of service offered, i.e.: full service or self-service.
   (c)    A sign in the station or individual signs over the islands indicating
the total price to be charged at the dispensing equipment for each grade of
motor fuel sold in accordance with the following:
      (1)    Whole numbers shall not be less than four inches in height and not
less than one-half inch stroke and any fractions shall be not less than fifty
percent (50%) of the whole numbers in both height and width.
      (2)    The price signs shall be placed in positions which are clear and
conspicuous to consumers when observed from any reasonable customer position
within the station and from the street area immediately adjacent to the
station's driveways.
         (Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.04 INSTALLATIONS.
   All installations for the self-service dispensing of motor fuels as herein
defined shall comply with the following provisions:
   (a)    No person shall cause the erection or alteration of any filling
station for motor fuels to include self-service dispensing devices without
first obtaining a permit from the Building Commissioner.
   No person shall engage in the operation of such a station without first
having obtained the aforesaid permit from the Building Commissioner.
   (b)    All self-service stations shall be under the supervision and control
of at least two authorized service station attendants at all times the station
incorporates split-island operation.
      (1)    The authorized attendants shall at all times have a clear and
unobstructed view of all self-service dispensing devices. There shall be no
obstruction on the premises which hinder the view between the attendants and
the self- service dispensing devices.
      (2)    All authorized attendants shall have a full knowledge of the
operation of emergency shutoff controls hereafter described.
      (3)    An attendant shall turn off the dispensing equipment serving any
person who refuses to follow the requirements as set forth in this Code, or the
instructions posted for operation of the self-service dispensing devices, or
who appears incapable of dispensing motor fuel safely.
      (4)    It shall be the responsibility of the station owner or manager to
instruct all employees in the use of the emergency shutoff controls, fire
extinguishing equipment, and all self-service dispensing equipment.
         (Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.05 TOILET FACILITIES.
   Toilet facilities shall be provided for the public.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.06 AIR PUMPS.
   Free air pump facilities shall be provided for the public.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.07 TIME LIMITATIONS.
   (a)   Self-service filling stations which are located less than one (1) mile
from an interstate highway or freeway on-ramp or off-ramp may remain open
twenty-four (24) hours a day in order to safely serve the motoring public.
   (b)   Self-service filling stations which are located more than one (1) mile
from an interstate highway or freeway on-ramp or off-ramp shall cease all
operations, including fueling and retail sales, between the hours of 10:00 p.m.
and 6:00 a.m. daily.
(Ord. 2024-052. Passed 5-7-24.)
755.08 SAFETY DEVICES.
   (a)   All tanks for the storage of flammable liquid used in conjunction with
self-service dispensing devices shall meet the requirements of this Code for
flammable liquid tanks. Automatic hose nozzle valves with latch open devices
are prohibited.
   (b)   All pipes supplying flammable liquids to approved self-service
dispensing devices shall be equipped with electrically operated shutoff valves.
All controls to such valves shall be in a centrally located area remote from
all dispensing devices and adequately protected from the weather and mechanical
injury. The valves shall be so designed as to close automatically in case of
electrical power failure. All electrical equipment shall be listed for use in
such areas.
   (c)   Every self-service station shall be provided with a minimum of one
approved fire extinguisher listed for use in Class B fires, rated 60BC or
larger and one additional extinguisher of the same type for each island. The
fire extinguisher shall be visible within fifty feet and shall be in place
during all hours the station is in operation. Extinguishers shall be protected
from weather and mechanical injury.
   (d)   Warning signs prohibiting smoking and instructing customers to turn
off ignition systems during filling operation shall be posted in a conspicuous
location at each island. Such signs shall have a white background with the
words “No Smoking” and “Turn Off Engine” in red letters, a minimum of four
inches high and with a minimum of a one-half inch stroke. Signs with directions
for operation of the dispensing devices shall also be provided.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.09 AGE LIMITATION.
   No person under the age of sixteen years shall be permitted to operate any
of the self- service dispensing equipment.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
755.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. Each day of such violation or failure to comply shall be
considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 1983-40. Passed 5-17-83.)
                                                                                                 
CHAPTER 757
Snow Plow Operators
757.01   Permit required.
757.02    Application for permit.
757.03    Effective date; revocation of permit.
757.99    Penalty.
 
 
   CROSS REFERENCE
   Responsibility of owner for snow and ice removal - see GEN. OFF.
543.03
 
 
 
 
757.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person, firm or corporation shall use a vehicle to plow or remove
snow from private property in the City for a fee or charge of any kind without
first securing a permit from the Police Department for such vehicle.
   (b)    No person, firm or corporation, being the owner, lessee, agent or
tenant having charge of lots or lands within the Municipality, shall allow any
person, firm or corporation to plow snow thereon, unless such person, firm or
corporation is licensed to do so under this section. (Ord. 1978-9. Passed 2-7-
78.)
757.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   (a)    The following information shall be provided by a person, firm or
corporation applying for the snow plow operator's permit required by Section
757.01:
      (1)    Name, home address, business address, state driver's license
number and telephone number;
      (2)    Make, model, serial number and state license plate number of the
vehicle or machine to be used for snow plowing and removal.
   (b)    The application for a snow plow operator's permit shall be
accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each vehicle
registered.
(Ord. 1978-9. Passed 2-7-78.)
757.03 EFFECTIVE DATE; REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   (a)    A snow plow operator's permit shall be effective during the period
from October 15 to April 15. A permit issued in one such time period is not
valid for a subsequent time period.
   (b)    A snow plow operator's permit is subject to revocation by the Chief
of Police upon the following grounds:
      (1)    Fraud or willful and knowing misrepresentation made in applying
for a snowplow operator's permit or made in the conduct of the snow plowing and
removal business.
      (2)    Failure to pay any fees as required by this chapter.
      (3)    Violation of any ordinances of the City pertaining to business
regulation or snow plowing and removal.
         (Ord. 1978-9. Passed 2-7-78.)
757.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 1978-9 . Passed 2-7-78.)
                                                                 
CHAPTER 759
Transportation of Radioactive Materials
759.01   Purpose and definitions.
759.02    Permit required.
759.03    Notice.
